The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

div.p: THE TRAGEDY OF ALBOVINE, KING OF THE LOMBARDS: By Wm. D'auenant.
LONDON, Printed for R. M. and are to bee ſold in Saint Dunstanes Church-yard. 1629.

div.head: TO THE RIGHT HONOVRABLE THE EARLE OF SOMMERSET, &c.
div.p: YOu read this Tragedie, and ſmil'd vpon't, that it might liue: and therein, your mercy was diuine; for it exceeded Iuſtice. My Numbers I not ſhew vnto the publike Eye, with an ambition to bee quickly knowne; (for ſo I couet noyſe, not fame) but that the world may learne, with what an early haſte, I ſtriue to manifeſt my ſeruice to your Lordſhip. I haue imaginations of a greater height then theſe, which I doe alſo dedicate to your Lordſhip. And I ſhall liue in vaine, vnleſſe you ſtill continue to acknowledge▪

div.head: VPON THE TRAGICK MVSE OF MY HONOVR'D FRIEND, Mr. Wm. D'AVENANT.
div.l: OVr ſtately Tragick Scene (whoſe high diſdaines
Slight humble Muſes) courts thy lofty ſtraines:
And with ambitious loue doth clime thy Bayes,
Whoſe ample branches her bright glory rayes:
Whence (as from Heauen) her ſpacious Eye doth view
Of ſtoryed teares, and blood, the heauy crue,
How low they crawle, while ſhe (farre more Diuine!)
Sides great Seianus, and fierce Cateline:
Where, in calme vertue, ſhe more ſweet doth ſhew
Then Ioue, when he in Golden drops did flow:
But if in Stygian Lake her veines ſhe ſteepe,
Her act infernall runnes ſo horrid deepe,
As ſaints Medea: makes th' Herculian rage
Seeme a tame patience to thy rauiſht Stage.
Had ſterne Achilles breſt ſuch fury knowne;
His Story had turn'd Miracle, and growne
Too much for his great Poet, vnleſſe Fate
Had rackt his ſpirit vp to thy high rate.
Raſh Imitation at thy heauenly Ayre,
Intombes faint Enuy in a iuſt deſpaire.

div.head: To his friend, Mr. Wm. D'auenant.
div.l: WHy ſhould the fond ambition of a friend,
With ſuch Induſtrious accents ſtriue to lend
A Prologue to thy worth? Can ought of mine
Inrich thy Volume? Th' haſt rear'd thy ſelfe a Shrine
Will out-liue Piramids; Marble Pillars ſhall,
Ere thy great Muſe, receiue a funerall:
Thy wit hath purchas'd ſuch a Patrons name
To deck thy front, as muſt deriue to Fame
Theſe Tragick raptures, and indent with Eyes
To ſpend hot teares, t'inrich the Sacrifice.

div.head: To my honor'd Friend, th'Author, on his Tragedy of the warlike Albouine.
div.l: GReat Albouine, whoſe Fate in warre had cut
His paſſage through the neighb'ring Earth, and ſhut
Large Prouinces within his graſping palme,
Had ſunke from honour in the patient calme
Of a long ſilenc't Fame, had not thy pen
(With ſoaring language) rays'd him vp agen.
He vowes, by coole Elizeum (from whence
He breath'd the valiant oath) he would diſpenſe
With all thoſe ioyes that court his ſoule, to fling
His open'd breſt vpon the poys'nous ſting
Of rougher warres, if the triumphant Bayes
Sprung from thy inke, might crowne his ſecond prayſe.
This is a Poets height; conqueſt by thee
Deſcrib'd, becomes a double victory.

div.head: To my deſeruing Friend, the Author.

lg.l: WEre thoſe Tragedians, whom the world ſo fame,
For their ingenious and admired ſtraine,
Aliue, to ſee this Poem, and thy Name;
Aſham'd they'd dye, finding their Lines too vaine.
Were that pure Spring the winged hoofe brought forth,
Wanting ſupply, dry'd vp, thy abler Pen
Would worke a ſecond wonder by it's worth,
In making it a running ſtreame agen.
Be then aſſur'd, this Tragick ſtraine ſhall liue
A patterne for th' next age to imitate,
And to the beſt wits of our times ſhall giue
Iuſt cauſe of enuy, for thy learned Fate.

div.head: To his noble Friend, th'Author on his Tragedy of Albouine.
div.l: THe gelid North growes warme, and by thy fire
Cold ignorance exil'd. The Virgin Quire
O' th' ſoft-hayr'd Muſes leaee the Theſpian Spring,
To tread a fun'rall Meaſure, whilſt you ſing
This Tragick Storie▪ With ſad plaints of loue
Fam'd Orpheus charm'd rude heapes, did Cedars mooue,
Forc'd Mountaines from their ſtation: but thy Pen
Hath now amaz'd the firie ſoules of men.

div.head: To my Friend, Mr. D'auenant.
div.l: SCarce home return'd, but ſtraight I finde great Fame
Ayring her wings to ſpread abroad thy Name.
One of the Nine (before of me ne'r ſeene,
Sure ſent by thee) aſſaults my merry ſpleene
With mighty Verſe; and makes me laugh at thoſe
That are ſo dull, to melt their thoughts in Proſe.
I wiſh her proſp'rous flight, may ſhe returne
With happier wings, if happier may be worne.
My flame is ſpent. I dare not vndertake
Thy praiſe, who am but newly for thy ſake
A fierce Poet, and doubtleſſe had been one
Ne'r but for thee, or elſe had been vnknowne.

div.head: To his much-honour'd friend, the Author.
div.l: LEt not loud Enuy's ſulph'rous blaſts caſt forth
Ʋenom'd aſperſions, on thy noble worth:
'Gainſt ſaucy Criticks thou need'ſt no defence,
Whoſe ſacred lines, arm'd with ſweet eloquence,
Are proofe againſt their cenſures, whoo'd prophane.
With their bold breath, the glory of thy ſtraine:
Wiſe came ſhall ſing the prayſe of thy deſerts,
And voyce thee glorious both in Armes and Arts.
Whilſt thou, releaſt from the Warres ſad miſhaps,
Reſts in ſoft dalliance on the Muſes laps;
Thoſe beautious Ladies loue ſhall high aduance
Thy fame, whoſe worth exceeds my vtterance.
Their Tragicke falles, who in thy Scenes appeare,
Shall on theſe Monuments faire Trophees reare
Vnto their Fame. Thus are thy workes become
To be to them, as their Elizium.

div.head: To his worthy friend, Mr. Wm. D'auenant.
div.l: HAst thou vnmaskt thy Muſe? And ſhall the Aire
Breathe on her matchleſſe Fabrick? then repaire.
To ſome ſoft cenſure, leſt the churliſh ſence
Of Ignorance accrues thy recompence;
And hudwinkt Error doe ſurprize the Fame
Due to thy Story, and Ʋerona's name,
Whoſe limits Plinies and Catullus bred,
But in thy Muſe her ioyes are centupled:
For her inuention, truth, rare wit, and ſtate;
Copper-lac'd Christians cannot perſonate.
Her Tragick Scenes, like well-tun'd Chimes ith' Skie,
Leaue Time loud Ecchoes of thy memorie.

list.item: Paradine, A captiue Souldier, his Fauourite.
Hermegild, A captiue Stateſman, the Queenes Fauourite.
Vollterri, A Souldier, friend to both.
Rhodolinda, Captine, and Queene to Albouine.

body.head: THE TRAGEDY OF ALBOVINE, KING OF THE LOMBARDS.

div.head: Act the firſt. Scene firſt.
div.stage: Enter Paradine, Grimoald, Gondibert; the Drummes ceaſing.

sp.speaker: Paradine.
sp.p: GIue the word aloud?

sp.speaker: Grimo.
sp.p: Stand?

sp.speaker: Within.
sp.p: 1. Stand! 2. Stand! 3. Stand!

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: Our motion has been ſwift: wee
out-march Time.
Verona, (which with the mornings dim eye
We ſeem'd to view like Landſchaip, afarre off)
Is our full obiect now. She muſt repent;
Our King is Steward vnto Fate; the world
Receiue from him their deſtinies.

sp.speaker: Grimo.
sp.l: Sure, the Gouernour ſleepes. My Lord, is' • fit
We waite vpon ſuch Silkewormes, crepp'd in wooll?

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: Since we attaind the Towne not by aſſault,
But compoſition free, he ſhall expreſſe
Humilitie enough to meet vs at the Gate.

sp.speaker: Gondib.
sp.p: Here comes Hermegild.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: Haile, young ſouldier! My noble Paradine!
The King muſt hold my nature much excus'd,
If I do greet his ſafe approach with loue,
Leſſe violent then I expreſſe to thy
Rich ſoule. I am reſolu'd thou art in health,
And fauour with thy ſtarres.

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: Ere I returne your kinde ſalute, I would
After your faire charge inquire. Say the Queene
Smiles in captiuitie, my Valdaura
Hurts not her health with griefe; then I haue heard
Enough to make me cheriſh life.

sp.speaker: Hermig.
sp.l: Rhodolinda doth become her title
And her birth. Since depriu'd of popular
Homage, ſhe hath been Queene ore her great ſelfe.
In this captiuity nere paſſionate
But when ſhe heares me name the King, and then
Her paſſions not of anger taſte, but loue:
Loue of her Conquerour: he that in fierce
Battaile (when the Cannons ſulpherous breath
Clouded the day) her noble Father ſlew:
Our Royall Maſter once; now ſunke into
His ſoyle; where like the Lilly wither'd,
He neuer ſhall renew his growth agen.
My memory diſturbes my Tongue! Your faire
Valdaura makes the Queene her rare and iuſt
Example, and is in patience skilfull.

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: Know, Hermegild, no haſty minute paſs'd
(Since their captiuitie) wherein I fail'd
To be a ſutor to the King for both.
But he's in kindneſſe prompt, and ſtill doth ſpeake
Like Muſicke, when he Rhodolinda names:
You heare tis his edict we call her Queene?

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: Thy vanquiſh'd Country owes vnto thy fame
A tall Pyramid! The captiu'd virgins
Of our Nation ſhall in their laſt Dirges
Sing thy prayſe with mirth. O, I could grow old
Within thy ſight. Something we now muſt talke
Together, and heauen will liſten to't,
As to the breath of Saints—

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: I knew we ſhould haue vſe of conference:
Which made me begge the leading of the Vanne,
The more t'aſſiſt our opportune meeting.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.p: Afford your eares in priuat.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: Though Paradine looke flouriſhing, and like
A thing new bruſh'd; a flame of triumph,
(As if his father ſurfetted in ſome
O're-growne City when he got him) yet he
Hath in him ſeeds of warre, bold thoughts, and we
I'th Campe, eſteeme him honeſt too.

sp.speaker: Gond.
sp.p: He is our Kings Minion, ſleepes in his boſome.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: True, & the Royall foole greets him with ſuch
Rauenous kiſſes, that you would thinke, he meant
To eate his lips.

sp.speaker: Gond.
sp.l: The Captiue captiuates the Conquerour.
Three Moones haue not expir'd their vſuall change,
Since he was priſoner to the King; though now
His Fauorite.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: Th'art too loud! If thou'lt talke ſafely, go get
A ſore throat; hoarce men ſpeake low.
The captiu'd Rhodolinda, (whoſe father
Albouine depriu'd of life and kingdome)
Hath with ſuch amorous ſubtiltie behau'd
Her geſture, that Albouine is now her
Priſoner. This martiall progreſſe was but made
To viſit her. She makes him guilty of
Idolatry, and knowes the thrifty vſe
Of time: as ſhe aſcends, her Countrimen
Muſt riſe.

sp.speaker: Gond.
sp.p: You haue call'd that Hermegild her Creature?

sp.speaker: Grimo.
sp.l: He was her fathers Councellor; a man
Created in the darke: he walkes inuiſibly;
He dwels in Labyrinths; he loues ſilence:
But when he talkes, his language carries more
Promiſcuous ſenſe, then ancient Oracles.
So various in his ſhapes, that oft he is
Diſgu • z'd from his owne knowledge. An error
Much incident to humane Politicks,
Who ſtriue to know others more then themſelues.

sp.speaker: Gond.
sp.p: Obſerue their complement.

sp.speaker: Grimo.
sp.l: Pox o' theſe French ligges? Courtiers alwaies dance.
This is to Hermegild meere lechery:
This wanton geſture doth obſcure
Thoughts of ſuch conſequence and weight, as hang
Like Plummets on his heart. Paradine is
A ſoft, eaſie foole, and muſt be guld.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: O my ſweet Lord—

sp.speaker: Grimo.
sp.p: Now the Motion ſpeakes.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: Such indeerements would too much impoueriſh
My gratitude: yet, tis meet our actions
Carry ſmooth equalitie: your conſent
Muſt further all my Sutes You are the Kings
Iewell, and hang richly in his eare.

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: You are precious vnto her, whom loud noiſe
Already calls our Queene: faire Rhodolinda!
We may (if they prooue naturall and kinde)
Gouerne the Nation that hath conquered vs;
Gaine our Countrey liberty, and yet
Not ſtray from noble Arts: ſuch hopes our free
Imbraces prophecy. The King.

sp.speaker: Frollo.
sp.l: Your Troopes (Sir) are ſo diuided into
Mix'd files, that to the City you doe march
Betweene thick walles of men.

sp.speaker: Albou.
sp.l: Let my Horſe-guard bring vp the Rere. We'le ſport
With warre. We haue no vſe of ſafety now,
But of magnificence.

sp.speaker: Vollterri.
sp.l: The order is already giuen. It was
Your Royall will, we haſten in our March,
Therefore each Squadron double their paces.

sp.speaker: Albou.
sp.l: My Boy, I bring thee home my chiefe Trophy:
Thou doſt delight me more then victory.
Retire. I am in loue too violent.
My embraces cruſh thee, thou art but yet
Of tender growth—

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: My Countriman would kiſſe your Royal hands,
And then expect no greater happineſſe
Till he arriue in heauen. He hath done your
Rhodolinda ſeruice— Preſents Hermeg. on his knee to the King.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: Rhodolinda is your humbleſt captiue.
She inſerts you often in her prayers,
And call'd it my chiefe duty to preſent
Her true ſeruice to your Maieſty.

sp.speaker: Albou.
sp.l: Her name doth inrich our Language. My boy
Can witneſſe that I loue her: ſhe makes me
Prattle in my ſleepe: I'ue drunke Mandragora,
To become drowzie, in hope that I might
Dreame of her. Riſe, and expect Honour.

sp.speaker: Gouernour.
sp.l: High and ſacred Maieſty! Verona
Hath vnhindg'd her wide Gates: proud to admit
The fate of Kingdomes. Our crooked Matrones
Forget their age: and (as the ragged Earth
At the Springs warme approach) look freſh, & young,
To intertaine you. Our timorous Virgins
(With the bold Youth) ioyne in one wanton Quire
To ſing your welcome.

sp.speaker: Grimo.
sp.p: How the Spaniell fawnes, 'cauſe he dares not barke?

sp.speaker: Gouer.
sp.l: Th'amorous Vine clips not the ſhady Poplar
With ſuch regard (about whoſe moſſie waſte
She hangs a ſmiling Louer.) Our City is
By the reflection of your bleſt approach
Like Pelion deck'd, whom Tython's Miſtreſſe
(Leauing the weeping Eaſt) with brightneſſe guilds.
There's not a wrinkle left in all Verona,
Wherein pale ſorrow, or rebellious enuy
Can finde their loathed Manſion. Flattering ioy
Swells big each loyall boſome. All implore
You as their ſafety; who hath huſh'd the noiſe
Of diſcord, and loud warre.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: The Raſcall flatters, as if he had ſeru'd
His prentiſhip in Court.

sp.speaker: Albou.
sp.l: Th'aſt done me iuſtice, Gouernor, & know'ſt
The way to make me thankefull, but not proud.
I vnderſtand thou haſt with honor'd ſafety
Preſeru'd thoſe Iewels to thy charge committed,
(My Rhodolinda, and my Boys Valdaura.)
And ſo increas'd new motiues of our thanks.

sp.speaker: Gouer.
sp.l: Heauen has made your memory too humble,
Thus to record your creatures ſeruice.

sp.speaker: Albou.
sp.l: Let now the knotty Laborer ruſt with eaſe,
And aloud proclaime, that the vpland Boore
Releaſe his Teeme, and his induſtrious Plough.
Let him ſing glad Iös to the ruſtick
Powers that guard his fields, and vnto me.

sp.speaker: Gouern.
sp.l: It is by you we are: no warlike Ram,
Nor battering engine forc'd a bloody entrance
Through our thicke walls. It was the powerfull breath
Of your victorious fame, that conquer'd vs.
To that we yeelded: which as a rough blaſt
That poaſts from the cold Artick Pole, hath borne
Before it captiu'd Nations.

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.l: By heauen a good old man! if he be learn'd,
Ile haue him write my Annales.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.p: Indeed he lookes like a Chronicler.

sp.speaker: Albou.
sp.l: Paradine? Informe him of my deeds.
Thou haſt beheld my diſcipline full of
Shape and order, when confuſion did oppreſſe
The foe, and ſtifled them in throngs. Hah! Looke!
Rhodolinda's come to guild our Triumph!

div.stage: Enter Rhodolinda, Valdaura, Theſina, and Attendants in mourning.

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: And my Valdaura too! let Nature ſhew
A third obiect ſo delightfull, we'le ſweare
She is not old, nor her firſt materials
Waſted, but in creation ſtill retaines
Her former ſtrength and skill.

sp.speaker: Albou
sp.l: But why (my beautious Captiue) art thou ſtill
In Sables wrapp'd?

sp.speaker: Rhodo.
sp.l: Your ſtarres bid you be happy. My croſſe fa • e
Like the Rauen, croaks a funerall note:
This ſwarthy habit, but paints forth the griefe
That chaines my ſoule in darkneſſe. And filiall loue
Commands me mourne for him, whom you too ſoone
Depriu'd of life, my conquer'd father.

sp.speaker: Albou.
sp.l: Let his aſhes reſt
At quiet in their Vrne. His ghoſt long ſince
Hath waſh'd away the memory of his fate
In ſlow-pac'd Laethe. Take me, modeſt faire,
Into thy boſome. O hide me there!
My glad ſoule, how full is thy content?
Now thou fear'd thing, that guid'ſt the heauenly Empire,
Rend all the murmuring clouds, and dart
Thy Thunder at me: I am ſafe.

sp.speaker: Rhodo.
sp.l: My captiuity muſt needs ſeeme eaſie,
Whilſt the Conquerour proues ſo kinde.

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.l: I could gaze thus on thee, till my wonder
Did conuert me into marble; and yet
My ſoule would in her ſelfe retaine a fire,
Liuely as that which bold Prometheus ſtole.
Were the Sea coagulate, and the world
Returnd to th' antick Chaos, a blinde Lumpe;
Thy looke would force the warring elements
Into a ſacred order; and beget
A harmony like this they now inioy.

sp.speaker: Rhodo.
sp.p: You are too powerfull in you ſpeech.

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.l: Yet when I valew thus thy excellence,
Let me not forget my owne high being.
I'ue humbled all the Nations of the earth;
Brought home as ſpoyles the whole wealth of Nature:
Yet, Rhodolinda, nought like thee. Let me
Whiſper my content, for ſoft muſicke moſt
Delights the female eare. They walke aſide.

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: Why, my deare Valdaura, doſt thou ſuſpect
My warme embraces? Let hungry death ceaze
On my honour, before it ceaze on me,
If in my breſt I intertaine a thought
Vnlawfull.

sp.speaker: Vald.
sp.l: I eſteeme you (Sir) a friend to vertue,
And in that hope would cheriſh all your loue.

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: In thy faire brow, there's ſuch a Legend writ
Of timorous chaſtitie, that it doth blinde
Th'adulterous Eye. Not the Mountaine Ice,
(Congeal'd to Chriſtall) is ſo froſty chaſte
As thy victorious ſoule, which conquers Man,
And Mans proud Tyrant-paſſion. But I am
Too rough for Courtſhip, the ſoft harmony
Which wanton Peace inſtructs the Tongue to make,
I haue forgot. Truſt me (bright Maid!)
I loue thee dearely. Though I'ue found thy heart
Like Pibble, ſmooth, but ſtony.

sp.speaker: Valda.
sp.l: I'ue heard my mother ſay: the curled Youth
Of Italy, were prompt in wanton ſtealths,
And ſinfull Arts. Till Time had giuen me
Aſſurance of your noble thoughts; 'twas ſafe
To doubt your loue. But now I wiſh I were
More worthy, and then would prooue more liberall
Of my ſelfe.

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: Let me enioy thy hand! that moyſt Adamant
That ſo attracts my ſoule! We will (ere night
Her black Curtaine drawes) make compleat this loue,
With marriage Rites.

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.l: How now, Boy! Is my intereſt ſo decay'd
In your young perſon, that you giue away your ſelfe
Without my leaue!

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: Humbly on my knee, I beg the vulgar
Priuiledge due to all hearts. To loue, and not enioy,
Is a torture, I cannot ſuffer long,
And ſtill remaine poſſeſs'd with breath.

sp.speaker: Albou.
sp.l: Thou haſt ſhew'd me phyſick for my paſſion.
Take him, Valdaura, and be proud! Tis I
That loue him: nor ſhall your ioyes be ſingle.
Ile make the number yet more full. This day
We'le conſecrate to Hymens vſe. Behold
Your Queene (who though my Captiue) for her birth
And beauty, is the firſt of Queenes.

sp.speaker: Gouer.
sp.p: High Heauen increaſe your ioyes!

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: And may you liue together vntill Time
Shall ſicken with his age.

sp.speaker: Frollo.
sp.p: Conrad. Long liue Albouine, King of the Lombards!

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.p: Cry vp Rhodolinda too!

sp.speaker: Frollo.
sp.p: Conrad. Liue Rhodolinda, Queene of the Lombards!

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Gouernor! Tis our will that you expect
Honour, and true ſafety. Your Cities loue
I ſhall perceiue by popular noiſe, and your
Behauiour in this great ſolemnitie.
Let the Sunne ſmile; the Winde ſport with our Plumes!
This day let ſick-men too forget to groane.
Let all glad Hymnes in one mix'd concord ſound,
And make the ecchoing heauen your mirth rebound.

div.stage: Exeunt all, but Grimold, Vollterri, Gondibert.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.p: The King's head muſt now conuert to rotten wood.

sp.speaker: Gond.
sp.p: Why, Grimold?

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: That Court Earewiggs may liue there, and deuoure
His brains. Doſt not perceiue how they begin
To creepe into his eares?

sp.speaker: Gond.
sp.l: Generous ſoules are ſtill moſt ſubiect to
Credulitie.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: He is a Germane in his drinke: buſied
With a wanton pride, which his Flatterers
Admire for mirth, but his friends doe pitie.

sp.speaker: Vollt.
sp.p: He ſhould be told his ſinnes.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: By whom? Vollterri, now the King forſakes
The Campe, he muſt maintaine luxurious mouthes,
Such as can vtter perfum'd breath, and theſe
Straite compoſe a faction, engroſſe his eares.
They limit ſtill his conuerſation.
Euen as the ſlow finger of the Diall
Doth in its motion circular remoue
To diſtant figures: ſo by a ſubtill
Leaſure, they doe prefix the houres,
When he muſt change his rotten Paraſite,
For one more skilfull, how t'admire, and praiſe.
No honeſt Tongue can euer interpoſe
To tell him he is mortall.

sp.speaker: Gond.
sp.l: It is the chiefe miſery of Princes,
Nere to vnderſtand their owne crimes, to ſinne
In ignorance.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: True, his Confeſſor, that in ſight externe
A Patriarke ſeemes, will gaine by flattery,
And ſuperſcribe vnto the King, as to the Pope
(His holineſſe.) But Gondibert,
Whom Conclaues here in Court doe canonize
For Saints, will ſcarce be admitted in heauen
For Angels.

sp.speaker: Vollter.
sp.l: Now Rhodolinda is become his Riuall
In high Soueraigntie, ſhe will permit
No errors but her owne: The King muſt mend
What ſhe miſlikes.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: She giues vs leaſure to expect
Her character. Women make themſelues more known
When they doe rule, then when th'obey.

sp.speaker: Gond.
sp.l: Valdaura is inrich'd with a ſweetneſſe
So religious, that Paradine muſt ſinne
In priuate, or need no mercy.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: Th'aſt nam'd her! Though my obdurate ſufferance
In actiue warre hath quite depriu'd me of
All amorous geſture. Though not theſe forty
Winters, I haue ſeene any of her ſex
But Suttlers wiues, who, in ſtead of Fillets,
Wrap their ſooty haire in Horſes girts. Though
My marrow is frozen in my bones,
Yet I melt before her eyes. When I ſee her,
I grow proud below the Nauell. For ſhe
Is none o' th' French Nourſery, that practice
The ſublime friske. None o' your ijgging Girles,
That pearch Paraqueeto's on their fiſts,
And ride toth' Court like Venus Falconers.

sp.speaker: Gond.
sp.l: Grimold, hoarce men ſpeake low, thou haſt not caught
A cold yet.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: She's none of thoſe that on their heads aduance
High, ſwagg'ring Plumes, like a gay Forehorſe
In a Country Teeme. O, ſhe's worth the tempting!

sp.speaker: Vollter.
sp.l: Doſt thou ſo commend her vertues, and yet
Wouldſt thou tempt her vnto vice?

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: That's a trick I learnt of the deuill. Thoſe
That are vertuous, need his temptation,
The wicked haue power enough to damne themſelues.

sp.speaker: Gond.
sp.l: Hark how they ſhowte! Away Grimold ▪ or we
Shall loſe the Triumph!

l.hi: Roome for Cuckolds, whoſe hornes are ſo high▪
They bore the Moone, as ſhe friskes in the skie▪

div.head: Act the ſecond. Scene firſt.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: This Peace makes me rotten, duſty
As a Cobweb. I liue like a Cricket
Ith'corner of an Ouen. Pox o' theſe oregrowne
Cities. To be valiant here, is to forfeit
The Statute: and theſe furr'd gownes hold,
There is no ſinne ſo great as pouerty.

sp.speaker: Gond.
sp.p: Thou art as melancholy as a leane Iudge!

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: I, or a corrupted Officer, at the noiſe
Of a Parliament. In this diuiſion
Of vnualewed Tropheys, Territories
Vaſt and ample, (gain'd partly by my ſweat)
Not a ſingle Acre falls to my ſhare.

div.stage: Enter Cunymond, Frollo, Conrade, Seruants with a Banquet.

sp.speaker: Cuny.
sp.l: Beare back there! They thruſt as if they meant
To get me with child—

sp.speaker: Frollo.
sp.l: You ſirrah! d'ye get the Kings officer
With child?

sp.speaker: Conr.
sp.l: Beare back there! or we'le put ye to the charge
Of Surgery—

sp.speaker: Cuni.
sp.p: Diſpatch▪ fellowes!

sp.speaker: Gondib.
sp.p: Is not that Cunymond?

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: The ſame. He is a great Aſtrologer.
The meere Anotamy i'th front o'th Kalender.
You may know where the Signe is, by ſome toy
In's habit, which he remoues, as the Signe
Remoues.

sp.speaker: Cuny.
sp.p: Frollo, did they enter here by your permiſſion?

sp.speaker: Frollo.
sp.p: Not by mine, Sir.

sp.speaker: Cuny.
sp.p: Nor yours, Conrade?

sp.speaker: Conrad.
sp.p: They are men of China for ought I know.

sp.speaker: Cuny.
sp.l: Then they muſt out. Gentlemen, pray auoide
The Preſence.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.p: 'S death Sir! d'ye make vs your Voyders?

sp.speaker: Vollter.
sp.l: Muſt we carry away your Cheeſe-parings?
Thruſt your Bodkins forth!

sp.speaker: Gond.
sp.p: Draw i'th Preſence? Art thou mad?

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: How he ſtands? he is created of Starch,
And dares not vſe a boyſterous motion,
Leſt he ſhould fall in Rumples.

sp.speaker: Cuny.
sp.l: Sir, you may ſpeake like a Cannon! but you
Shall either goe, or—

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.p: Or what, Sir?

sp.speaker: Cuny.
sp.p: Or ſtay, Sir.

sp.speaker: Conrad.
sp.l: By heauen he ſhall doe one, Sir—

sp.speaker: Frollo.
sp.l: Nay, Captaine, doe not look, as if y'had drunk
Vineger. You muſt, or go, or—ſtay Sir—

sp.speaker: Cuny.
sp.l: Hey! we are tumbling in a Drum.
Within. Fellowes o' the Guard, make way there! Officers!
Open the doore—

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: Beare back there! Gentlemen! what d'ye meane?
Pray' beare back—

div.stage: Enter Albouine, Rhodolinda, Paradine, Valdaura, Hermegild, Theſina, &c.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: Phoebus will be thought more raſh then Phaeton,
If now he haſten to the Weſt. Sir, this
Glorious day, merits well a longer age,
Then what is limitted to all within
Our Kalender.

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.p: Hermegild, thy free heart adds to our triumph!

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: Sir, I'ue ſome few words, I needs muſt vtter:
Since my laſt ſeruices in Hungary,
You remaine on my Tally ſix thouſand
Duckats: I'm loth to skore vp ſtill, and pay
My ſelfe with my owne Chalke.

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.p: Wouldſt haue thy Soule diſmiſſed a naturall way?

sp.speaker: Gri.
sp.l: I would not ſtarue, looke, like a parch'd Anotamy
Sow'd in a Kid-skin. Pay your debts, Sir!

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.l: I neuer met with boldneſſe, vntill now!
My courage is quite puzled!

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: Do your eares bliſter to heare this? My breath is
Wholſome. I cannot tipple like a Duck
In a greene Poole. Nor feed on Berries in
A Hedge, like ſome loſt remnant o' my fathers
Scatterd luſt. Sir, pay your debts!

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.p: Sure, thou art ſome ſpirit! I cannot kill thee!

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: In this diuiſion of the Lands, I help'd
To conquer; I am not furniſh'd with
A Mole-hill for a pillow.

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.l: Hermegild ſat chiefe in the Committee
For diuiſion of thoſe Lands: bid him reward
Your ſeruice: beſides, I miſtake the cuſtome,
Or tis my Treaſurers office to pay
My debts, not mine.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: No Sir, (thanks to your Royall thrift) it is
Your office to pay all; your Treaſurers
Cuſtome to pay nothing. Thruſts him away.

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.p: Do not interrupt my marriage Rites!

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.p: I cannot take your reference for paiment.

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.p: Would thou wert dead!

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: Sir, Ile make my Ghoſt, my Executor,
And walke after death, ere Ile loſe my mony.

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.l: Sit, my Rhodolinda: This is thy Spheare!
In th'abſence of the Sunne, we muſt receiue
Our light from thee. Paradine, thy Bride expects
Thy ſeruice.

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: Sh'as an ill bargaine on't, to rule one night,
And euer after to obey.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: Captaine, though the King be prompt in mercy,
Yet hath he ſo much anger in him,
As will expreſſe him mortall. Tis for your
Safety, to auoid the Preſence.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.p: Ile bribe your Lordſhip with a Ginny Toothpick!

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.p: You muſt repent this language.

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.p: He muſt not, Hermegild!

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.p: How, my Lord!

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: Theſe whom you number in your faction,
Enioy, by your aſſiſtance, proud ſtructures;
And fertill Granges, to maintaine their gaudy
Riot. Sir, you had a fraile memory,
Or a degenerate heart, when you forgot
His merit; might you incorporate thoſe in one,
The ſordid bulke could nere make vp his ſhadow.

sp.speaker: Hermeg.
sp.p: I am preſcrib'd my diſcipline in Court!

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: Grimold, away! Tis my deſire you leaue
The Preſence.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.p: I am obedient (Sir) to your deſire.

sp.speaker: Gond.
sp.p: 'Slight, thou haſt made a braue retreat.

sp.speaker: Vollt.
sp.l: I look'd when both of vs ſhould taſte
Of immortalitie.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: He that inflam'd this fire, will ſcorch his buſie
Fingers. My Lord, it was vnkindly done
T'affront my anger thus: but I haue hope
It is your laſt fault.

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: I cannot reckon it among my faults.
Sir, you inuolue your meaning in your ſpeech.
The world ſhall finde me honeſt.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.p: You are a Bridegroome now.

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.l: Hermegild, make your anger knowne,
For elſe your frownes will cauſe your loyaltie
To be ſuſpected. This night ſhould be as ſmooth
And pleaſant, as that to which we owe our bleſs'd
Natiuitie.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: Sir, you are great on Earth! I am meerely
Your creation. My paſſions doe afford
Your high delight all ſympathy.
Old Time hath throwne his feathers from his heeles,
And ſlowly limps in's motion to prolong
This Triumph: but if Paradine affront
Hymen, and me with ſullen rage, it ſhall
Be call'd my piety to ſuffer.

sp.speaker: Rho.
sp.l: How! your Excellence ought t'excuſe my ſpeech!
VVhen your victorious ſword depriu'd me of
My Father; I enter'd to captiuity,
As to th'oblique ſhade, where death inhabits.
Till you allowd me Hermegild; who with
His high Philoſophy did make
My bondage ſweete. My Father lou'd him well:
He was his nobleſt Seruant, and muſt not
For his vertues ſuffer, vntill your ſacred tongue
Forbid me ſhare with you in Soueraignty.

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.l: Boy, this was a bold crime. You muſt not giue
Me cauſe to chide my fond heart. Valdaura,
Vrge him to proffer friendſhip
Vnto Hermegild; you are powerfull
Ore his nature. I haue deſeru'd to loſe
My chiefe prerogatiue—

sp.speaker: Vald.
sp.l: I am too timorous to deale with anger:
If he prooue ſterne of nature, my Marriage
Is my funerall. My Lord!

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: Paradine, I'ue an humble loue. I will
Preſent it firſt to your refuſall—

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: I want your phraſe, to make my manners ſeeme
Leſſe rugged. All that is loue, I cheriſh
With ſuch religious heate, as my Valdaura
Claimes, ſince our young Nuptiall—

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.l: This embracement is a ſacrifice
To thee my Queene: whoſe deity
Conſiſts of loue. Sit, and with your
Perſons, ſtraight intrench the Table. Some wine!
Fill in my Germane Plate; Ile drinke as when
I'm hot with victory. This to my Bride—

sp.speaker: Cuny.
sp.p: Sound high!

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.l: More wine, and noiſe! Now Boy, I celebrate
Valdaura's health —

sp.speaker: Cuny.
sp.l: Bid their Inſtruments ſpeake lowder.
They're afraid to wake the Neighbours.

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.l: This is legitimate blood of the rich
Corſick Grape: precious as thy teares
(My Royall Girle) when thou art penitent
To heauen. Whileſt the King talkes, they drinke.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: Spare me in the next, and Ile eſteeme you
Courteous; ſo much wine will put me to the charge
Of Phyſicke.

sp.speaker: Cuny.
sp.p: Your Lordſhip ownes it as a prime vertue —

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.l: Shall the world bleed? but frowne, and thou renew'ſt
A Chaos. Maligne the pride of ſome farre
Eaſterne Queene, whom Trauellers bely,
And I will forage there, like loud thunder!
Or like the Northerne winde vpon the Maine,
Where lazie Hulkes are toſs'd like chips.

sp.speaker: Rhodo.
sp.p: I merit no ſuch complement.

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.l: Ile do't. Tis thought, I am immortall.
The chiefe of my great Anceſtors, that made
A wilde incurſion ore this fertill ſoile,
Was but a tipe of me. More wine! — Thy breath
Is as the ſmoke of ſpices. I taſte thy
Melting lippes, and ſtraight ingender kiſſes.
Heart! Boy, you are too rauenous!

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: I euer held your Maieſty my beſt
Example. Kiſſes nimbly gather'd,
The faſter grow.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.p: The Lombards vſe to ſhare this ſport! He kiſſes Theſina.

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.p: Is not your name Pigwiggin?

sp.speaker: Cuny.
sp.l: Pigwiggin! your Grace was wont to call me
Cunymond: I am no Faery.

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.l: Nor I the King of Faeries. 'Slight, ſir, d'ye
Preſent me with a Cup, made, o'th bottome
Of an Akehorne, or Queene Mabbs Thimble?
Fill me a bowle, where I may ſwimme,
And bathe my head, then riſe like Phoebus from
The Ocean, ſhaking my dewy Locks.
A health to Ceſars memory. Boy, doe me
Iuſtice, or thou afrontſt my Triumph!

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.p: Conrade, the King will drowne vs all!

sp.speaker: Conr.
sp.p: Y'haue now, Sir, but the moiety of his draught.

sp.speaker: Rhodo.
sp.l: Though Fame lends you her Trumpet, giues you leaue
To ſpeake your owne praiſe, you cannot vtter more
Then my beliefe ſhall warrant.

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.l: Now thou whiſper'ſt like the amorous Lute!
I am the Broome of Heauen, whē th'world grows foule,
Ile ſweepe the Nations into'th Sea, like duſt.
Thy father was magnanimous, and great
King of the Girpides. Yet his title
Sat not ſo nobly on him, as my conqueſt.
Know, his vnkind fate, was his chiefe glory:
For it was I that ſlew him; and thou his
Captiu'd Daughter art my Queene.

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.l: Sir, if you continue this narration,
I ſhall weepe.

sp.speaker: Albou.
sp.l: Doe, weepe! then on my heart-ſtrings I will thread
Thy teares in ſtead of Pearle: ſuch a wealthy
Bracelet, loue would preſent vnto his Queene:
And ſhe tuck vp her ſleeues, to ſhew her gawdy wriſts.
More wine! Bring vs the Bowle of Victory.

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: Sir, you ingag'd your Royall word, neuer
To preſent that fatall obiect.

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.l: Paradine, doe not reſiſt my pleaſure.
Ile cruſh thee into Ayre.

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: I am in my ambition vertuous,
If I deſire t'expire a ſacrifice
To loyaltie. Sir, ruine what you made,
But doe not violate your Vow.

sp.speaker: Albou.
sp.l: Hence! I ſhall delight in fury!
sp.stage: Enter Cunymond with a Skull, made into a drinking-Bowle.
sp.l: Welcome, the horrid Trophey of my chiefe warre!
Rhodolinda, Ile try thy fortitude.
This was thy Fathers Skull: thou ſhalt pledge a health
Vnto his Ghoſt. He drinks▪ all riſe vp.

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.l: O fatall! my eies ſhrinke within my brow!
I gather Agues like the Spring, and tremble
Like the vnlick'd Lambe, newly yeand vpon
A ſheete of Snow.

sp.speaker: Vald.
sp.l: Hide me, Paradine! the obiect doth ſo
Penetrate, that when I winke, I ſpie it
Through my Lids.

sp.speaker: Albou.
sp.l: Tame, feeble Soule! Will ſhe not pledge
What we doe celebrate? Returne her perſon—

sp.speaker: Cunym.
sp.l: Madam, the King— Strikes him, and exit.

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.p: The King's a Tyrant, and thou his ſlaue.

sp.speaker: Frollo.
sp.p: That's a fauour, Signior.

sp.speaker: Cunym.
sp.p: I weare it as a Iewell in my eare.

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: Fly, deare Valdaura; ſweeten her cenſure
Of this act, and mediate for the King.

sp.speaker: Vald.
sp.l: Theſina, prethee helpe me in diſcourſe;
My wonder (Wench) doth ſo diſturbe my ſpeech,
I feare I ſhall grow dumbe.

sp.speaker: Theſi.
sp.p: The work is pious we attempt.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: The harmony of your ſweet tongue is his
Beſt phyſicke: diuorce him from thoſe black thoughts,
Whil'ſt I imploy my vtmoſt skill, to win
The Queene to his imbraces. She's great of Soule,
And may determine what my fond heart laments
To prophecy.

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.p: Y'are my beſt Countriman, kind and loyall.

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.l: So pale and timorous! Ile ſooner couple
With a Mandrake, and beget groanes.

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.p: My Royall Lord!

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.l: Hah! Am I alone? Haue they all left me?
Where is my Empire? Doe I gouerne in
The vacant Ayre?

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: Sir, am I loſt vnto your memory?
You were wont to truſt my ſeruice: the way
Vnto your Couch lyes here—

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.l: None ſhall be proud but I. My ſmiles reuiue
The dead: but when I frowne, the liuing ſtraight
Melt into Ghoſts.

sp.speaker: Cunym.
sp.p: Lights for the King there!

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: Cunymond, you are too officious! The Kings
Departure muſt be priuat.

sp.speaker: Frollo.
sp.l: The King is light enough himſelfe: he needs
No Torches.

sp.speaker: Cunym.
sp.l: And heauy enough! for he ſeemes to reele
With his owne weight.

sp.speaker: Conrad.
sp.l: No Maskes! No Epithelamion now!
Call for a Boneſetter, for Time hath ſprain'd
His feete, and goes awry.

sp.speaker: Rhodo.
sp.l: O Hermegild! a generall eclips
In Nature, would not ſeeme ſo horrid!
To cut thoſe cordiall ſtrings which Hymen had
But newly ty'd.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: I, there's the horror! whil'ſt his Vowes ſat warm
Vpon his Lips; his breath not mingled yet
With cooler Ayre; thus to perturbe by ſterne
Practice your ſweet reſt, was worſe then periury.

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.l: To preſent my Royall Fathers Skull,
In drunken Triumph.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: Take heede! you will diſtract your memory.
There's a Record, Time ſtriues to loſe; and Fame
To hide beneath ſome oblique fold in her
Thicke Volume, as loth to diſcredit all
Mankind. Your father valewed you next to
His intereſt in heauen. I'ue ſeene the good
Old King ſearch for his picture in your eyes; then—

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.l: No more: Patience is ſinfull now. Thou art
Deepely read and wiſe: inſtruct me to be bold,
For Albouine hath taught me to be cruell.

sp.speaker: Hermeg.
sp.l: Y'are now by holy Church incorporate;
Therefore Diuinitie forbids me vſe
My naturall motions. How e're I thinke
It fit, you giue him direfull cauſe, ſoone to
Repent: Repentance ſure is phyſick for his ſoule.
Paradine and 's young Bride! Your excellence
Shall pleaſe that we retire: whil'ſt I diſguize
My kind geſture, and ſeeme to flatter in
The Kings behalfe—

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: To bed ſoft modeſty! I will my ſelfe
Deliuer to the Queene the King's intent.

sp.speaker: Vald.
sp.l: Sir, the King is cruell. Should you proue ſo
To me, I'ld ſoone diſtill my ſoule to teares,
And weepe an Ocean deepe enough to drowne
My ſorrowes, and my ſelfe.

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: 'Twere ſterne guilt to doubt my nature. Faire Saint,
To bed, I long to loſe my Youth in warme
Embraces, and ere the pearly Morne appeare,
Make thee a teeming Mother. To bed! with winged haſt
Expect my preſence.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.p: How ſmooth appeares the Brow of Youth!

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: Haile Rhodolinda! the Royall Miſtreſſe
Of this night. Thus Albouine (our great King) bade
Me ſay, Y'are dearer to his eyes then light.
Though euery Bride may claime from Hymen
Priuiledge to rule her Lord, till Heſperus
Appeare, and cancell her briefe Charter.
Yet he doth humbly beg, you'le not infringe
The Lombards cuſtome, whoſe Virgins neuer vow
A continence the Nuptiall night.

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.p: I yet want your meaning.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Tis his chiefe hope that you will ſtraight expect
His perſon in your bed.

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.l: How! lye with him? Ile ſooner chooſe a Manſion
In a ſepulcher: There commit inceſt
With the raw remnant of my fathers bones:
Sooner imbrace an ayrie Incubus:
Mingle Limmes with ſome vlcerous Cripple,
Able to infect an Hoſpitall.

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: O take heed! Take heed, faire Maieſty! let not
His raſh ſinne prouoke you to intend ſo dire
An abſtinence: ere yet the wine hath loſt
Th'vnruly operation. The King diſclaimes
His wanton pride, and mortifies himſelfe
VVith ſullen griefe.

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.l: Canſt thou ſuſpect, I will prooue inconſtant,
To what in cold temperance I determine?

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.p: Heauen auert you ſhould approue your error.

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.l: Ile kneele, and vow with all ſolemnitie—

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: O hold! 'twere blacke impietie in vs
To ſuffer ſuch a horrid crime. You may
Informe the King of my religious loyalty,
Already I haue vs'd perſwaſiue ſpeech
To reconcile this ods: but ſhe growes wilde,
Repugnant to all mercy.

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: As you eſteeme your Royall ſelfe, or vs,
Who (when kinder Planets rul'd) were ſeruants
To th'vnhappy King your father; cheriſh
No more this anger in your breſt, leſt Time
Afford it growth and violence, till it
Diſturbe the world.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.p: He councels like a ſacred Oracle.

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: I will informe the King, your continence
You onely celebrate to this blacke night,
And giue him hope, that you'le hereafter ſmile,
His kinde inticements meet with equall heate,
And fertill loue. Though I'm vnhewne, and ſhap'd
In warre, this ſoftens all my faculties—

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.p: Stay, Paradine; didſt thou not name my Father?

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.p: I did with a deuout remembrance!

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.p: And thou know'ſt how thy good Country ſuffers?

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: I think on it, and my heart hangs heauy
On its ſtrings; galles them with its ſullen weight.

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.l: Hermegild oft receiues certificate
From ſome in bondage there, which writ in Proſe, doe,
I'th reading into Verſe diſſolue: ſo ſad
The buſineſſe is, ſo fit for elegie.

sp.speaker: Hermeg.
sp.l: So ſad a Requiem yet was neuer ſung,
Though the hoarce Rauen, and the Whiſtler ſhrill,
The Howlet, and the euening Dorr made vp
The fatall Quire. The young men there are yoak'd
In payres, and ſtretch their ſinnews in a Teeme,
To draw the wealthy harueſt to the Grange,
Where th'inſulting foe reſides. The aged
(Heretofore in purple cloth'd) that diſpos'd
Of Law and Iuſtice; are now ſow'd vp
In dunghill clouts; and dwell on parched hills,
To tend the flocks; whoſe fleece the Victor weares
In gawdy triumph.

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: O harſh captiuitie! Our Country groanes!
Till now I thought the Conqueror gan to eaſe
Their bondage, not adde to the weight of their
Compell'd burdens.

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.p: The King's a ſterne Tyrant.

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: Yet he hath vs'd me ſtill with gentle power,
Ta'ne me from the cold Earth, and warm'd me in
His boſome: and Hermegild has full cauſe
To bleſſe his bounty. But you (now our Queene)
He valewes next to heauen; howe're this raſh
Error ſtriues to diſgrace his loue. We are
His captiues too; heretofore not heeded
By our Starres; though we now grow tall with titles
And his fauour.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: My Lord, the King is kinde! Our memories
Were fraile, ſhould we forget what hath ſo much
Pertain'd vnto our knowledge. I'm ſo fond
O're my Religion, I dare not taſte
Ingratitude: yet giue me leaue to ſay,
You may miſtake his loue vnto the Queene.
The dry Tartar, who yoakes his females neck
With ruſty Yron, not with Carckanets
Of threaded Pearle; whom he preſerues for phyſick
More then increaſe; will the firſt night of their
Coniunction, feaſt her in's imbroader'd tent;
Call her Soueraigne; and like ſome amorous winde,
Sport with her haire.

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.l: But my Nuptiall the King did celebrate
In Golgotha, where Skulls, and duſty bones
Inhabit.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: Y'are skilfull in the deeds that appertaine
To ſtrength and fury; but they that aime
At victory in Court, muſt practiſe ſmooth
And ſubtill Arts. Wiſe Fauourites doe walke
I'th darke, and vſe falſe lights. Nay, oft diſguize
Their breadth and ſtature; ſeeme leſſer then they are:
For know, the ſlender Worme, or nimble Grig,
May wriggle downe into th' oblique, and low
Deſcent o'th narrow hole; whilſt th'oregrowne Snake
Peepes at the brimme, but ne're can view the bottome.

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.l: Thinke on thy Country, Paradine! Is there
In Story no mention of ſome great Soule,
That did his Country prize aboue his owne
Mortalitie, and dy'd to gaine his Nation Freedome?

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: The Noble Brutus for his Countreys health,
Made Ceſar bleed; Caſsius was heroique too,
And had in warre loud Fame, which he increas'd
By mingling in this Act.— Tis wrought with skill,
And apt leaſure. His thoughts grow numerous,
And ingender horrid ſhapes; ſuch as fright
His fancy.

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.p: Paradine, good night!

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: Hymen and your Bride, will blame your tardy
Seruice. Sweet Lord, a thouſand times good night.

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: Falſe vnto me! when Thunder wakes the dead:
When the Skie looks ſwarthy: the clouds like inke
In water powr'd: when the Earth ſeemes to ſtand
As in a gloomy ſhade. When the winde blowes
Till it growes hoarce: till it conuert
And ſprinkle Seas euen to a Dew; then I
Shall try the King, and fathome his wide Soule.
If he ſtart, complaine of his mortalitie,
Kneele oft; and pray aloud, as Heauen
Were deafe: if thus, I will conclude him falſe.
For horrid ſtormes that Tyrants waking keepe,
Doe rock the noble Conſcience ſafe aſleepe. Exit.

div.head: Act the third. Scene firſt.

sp.speaker: Vald.
sp.l: I knew your Excellence did viſit me
For mirth and laughter.

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.p: So early vp? Your Lord is temperate.

sp.speaker: Theſ.
sp.l: I ſhould like their tempers better, if ſhe
Were downe, and her Lord vp.

sp.speaker: Vald.
sp.p: Fye, Theſina, your tongue's vnruly.

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.l: The morning might haue ſhewne me too for mirth,
Had not the falſe King made the night ſo ſad.
Black fancy flye!

sp.speaker: Theſ.
sp.l: She moues as ſhe were ſicke, this skirmiſh has
Much weakened her.

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.p: Doſt thou call't a skirmiſh?

sp.speaker: Theſ.
sp.l: I, Madam, a French skirmiſh; where th' onſet
Is hot and fiery, but the retreat cold and tame.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.p: Madam, the King?

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.p: Hah!

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: He greets your Excellence in a ſmooth phraſe,
And begs, you will permit his early viſit.

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.p: I'ld rather loſe my eyes then ſee him.

sp.speaker: Vald.
sp.l: When you did triumph in your fathers Court,
My entreaty then had power to alter
Your commands; reward my young ſeruice
With kindneſſe to your ſelfe. When the tall
Cedar falls, with burly weight it ſtrikes
The neighbouring ſhrubs, low, into the ground:
So we that ſpring like Ruſhes neere your roote,
Muſt in your death receiue a funerall.

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.p: VVhat's this? D'ye moralize?

sp.speaker: Vald.
sp.l: The King may haue his anger warranted.
For heauen forbids ſuch wilde diuiſion▪
'Tweene thoſe whom holy Church vnites.

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.l: Harke, Theſina! She has been goſſiping▪
VVith the holy Siſters: ſhe preaches to me
Of Matrimoniall zeale. Troth Valdaura,
If thy husband doe infuſe ſuch ſchiſme,
Ile practiſe a diuorce.

sp.speaker: Theſina.
sp.l: We Court Ladies grow ſo ſqueamiſh after
VVe haue taſted Man. Your Maieſty may
Much profit her behauiour, if you
A while deuide her from her Lord.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: So ſoone? Ere Time permits them ſecond
Their imbraces?

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.l: I Hermegild. If thoſe imbraces doe
Include ſuch high delight, ſuch rapſody;
She makes me enuious then▪ ſince all my hopes
Are widdowed by the King. To night, Valdaura ▪
You are to ſleepe beneath my Roofe. This I
Impoſe as a command.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.p: Is not this a harſh compulſion?

sp.speaker: Vald.
sp.l: Sir, I willingly obey it. But as
Y'are Noble, vſe your ableſt skill, t'inſtruct▪
The Queene how of her anger to diſpoſe
A ſafer way, then 'gainſt the King.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: Alas! I'ld rather cut my Eye-lids off
To preuent ſleepe then loſe one minute that
Could aduantage a deſigne ſo pious.
And be it part of your kinde charity,
T' indeere me to your Lord. Tis all the pride
In my ambition to doe him ſeruice.

sp.speaker: Vald.
sp.l: Sir, he already knowes your worth, and thinks
Your friendſhip precious. Exit.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: I kiſſe your faire hands. The King already come?
I muſt ſeeme penſiue as the night.

div.stage: Enter Albouine, Paradine, Cunymond, Frollo, Conrade.

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.l: She's loſt, my Boy: blowne from my fiſt: her wings
Haue gather'd wind: they flye (like thoſe of Time)
Swiftly forward, but neuer backe returne.

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: Sir, I haue hope, ſhe will repent this breach
Of duty, and court your Royall ſmiles agen.

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.l: Is it a ſinne to drinke? Nature has giuen
To fiſhes a prerogatiue, greater
Then we inioy. They can euer tipple
And not be drunke.

sp.speaker: Cuny.
sp.l: Fiſhes are dumb (Sir) they neuer fox themſelues
With talke.

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.l: Slaue! thy mirth is treacherous! Paradine!
Thou haſt conſum'd to night the wealth of loue,
Waſted thy lips in moyſt kiſſes, imbrac'd
A warmth, that would giue life to marble.
Whilſt I, (like the ſolitary Phoenix)
Expect no heate but in my funerall flame:
And ſtriue t'ingender of my ſelfe. Yet Boy,
Thou canſt not make me enuious; thou art more
Delightfull; then my Rodolinda's ſinnes.
Let me ſuruay thoſe blue circles: his lids
Fall downe, as if weighty Plummets hung on
Their ſinnes. Thou art not temperate. Preſerue
Thy deare eyes. Loue was pictur'd blind, becauſe
It makes men blinde. I hugge thee as my health —

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: He bruis'd me in his armes. Can loue expreſſe
Such violence, and yet be falſe? Hermegild
Still whiſpers in my eare, the King doth hate
Thee, Paradine. But Hermegild is read in all
The Arts of Court, and ſtriues perhaps
My ſence to poyſon with leane iealouſie.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: Sweet Lord! Y' appeare bluſhing like the Morne!
Something your Bride and you haue done t' increaſe
The number of the Worthies.

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: He courts me too! I want a Perſpectiue,
To draw theſe diſtant figures neere my ſight.
I ne're ſhall ſleepe agen.

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.l: Hermegild, thy aſpect ſhewes ominous!
How thriues our embaſie?

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: I haue conſum'd my breath, till I grew faint,
And wept to inuite her mercy; but teares
Were ſpilt like water in the Forge, onely
T' inrage the fire. She doth abiure your viſit.

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.p: Harſh, Iron, nature!

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: The King ſeemes fetter'd in his lims: he wreathes
His armes, as if he meant to bruiſe his heart.
And Paradine doth find my charmes predominant.

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.p: He that drinks, forfeits his mortalitie!

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.p: How Sir, muſt we not drink?

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.l: Souldier, to keepe thy bladder moyſt, I will
Permit thee gape i'th mornings face, and catch
Her mizzling teares.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: If you'll extirpate this vice of drinking,
Giue order for a priuy ſearch i'th the Ocean;
There dwell the greateſt drinkers. The VVhale (Sir)
Drinks deeper let's hale her on ſhore, and impownd her
In a Ceſterne.

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.l: Good! we will imbarke for Sea. I preſſe thee vp
For this imployment.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: Stay (Sir) ere I ingage my ſelfe in new
Seruices, pay me for my old. You reſt
Vpon my Ticket, ſix thouſand Duckats;
And I haue not ſeene your Maieſties face
In any other metall, but your owne
Fleſh and blood theſe three moneths.

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.p: Thou grumbleſt like a gray VVolfe.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.p: Tis then for hunger, Sir.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: Captaine, you miſtake the King. He's Royall
As his blood, and liberall as the Sunne
That ſhines on all. This vnruly breath, where
The Citie meete in councell, might perhaps▪
Blow their Purſe-ſtrings looſe, ſo fill the Exchequer.
And then you ſhall number your pay with your owne
Fingers.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: I will out-rore thunder, or the Cannon!
Muſt they ſtill walke in wealthy Furres; whilſt men
Of merit here are cloth'd in Cabidge leaues?

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.p: Grimold, you indanger your friends.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: My Lord, giue loſers leaue to ſpeake. I'ue loſt
My youth and blood ith'warres, and I want food,
A reuerend Aſſe beares my wife and her young egges
In Paniers vp and downe the ſtreets. I trauaile
Like a Tartar, with all my family
About me. Nay, nay, nay! you would be gon!

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.p: Art thou not yet dead?

sp.speaker: Gri.
sp.l: You muſt not moue, till y'haue paid me. I know,
You may be angry with more ſafety then I.
Bid ſome Coloſſus of your Guard cleaue me
With his Falchon; yet I ſhall ſteale a paſſage
Ore the blacke Riuer, when Charon ſlumbers,
And fright your Grace.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: I dare not ſtrike thee (old man) leſt thou ſhouldſt fall
To duſt, and choke me.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: Good King, pay me. I loue thy Grace:
And will fight for thee, whilſt I'ue motion left
To ſtirre a feather. My want conſtraines me to't.
By this hand, I'm faine to eate Branne and Parſley
Like a tame Rabbit.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.p: Lend me your eare, Captaine!

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.p: You'll intice me now t'enter into bond?

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: You look indeed like a young heire. Well, Sir,
Valew me according to my true rate.
I am your friend. You make ill choice of howers
For helpe of your deſigne. The King hath now
Sad and tumultuous thoughts about his heart.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: Great men are alwayes ſad, when they ſhould pay
Their debts.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: Sir, you interpret ill. Grow more ſober,
Then challenge all my power in your behalfe.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: He that receiues a kindnes from the Diuell,
Shall bee ſure to loſe by his gaines.

sp.speaker: Cuny.
sp.l: Captaine, you ſhould chuſe a luckier minute:
The King is now in loue.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.p: With whom?

sp.speaker: Frollo.
sp.p: With the Queene.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: In loue with his owne wife! that's held inceſt
In Court: varietie is more luſcious.

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.l: Be powerfull in thy ſpeech, my Paradine,
Yet gentle too. She is the Starre that rules
My faculties.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: The Queen will bleſſe your temperance, & repent.
Hermegild is too buſie: he muſt be more
At leaſure, and I more actiue.

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.p: Hermegild, weare thy ſences neere vs—

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: Your Maieſty has a fraile memory
To forget me ſo ſoone—

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.p: You'll forfeit me, and the Kings mercy! away!

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: Tis no piece of vnkindneſſe to wiſh thee
In hell, for all thy friends dwell there. Th'aſt none
Vpon the earth. Gentlemen will you be open to me?

sp.speaker: Cuny.
sp.p: In all parts, Sir, but our purſes.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: Draw neere! let vs communicate our hearts!
Does not that wealth, which you disburſe for powders,
Perfumes, clothes, and phyſicke for the face,
Returne with gaine?

sp.speaker: Frollo.
sp.p: Expound your Riddle, Sir.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: Haue you not each a Miſtreſſe that maintaines
You in expence and riot? Hah? Fame giues
It out, you ſmooth Gallants are much oblig'd
Vnto the ſinnes of Ladies.

sp.speaker: Cuny.
sp.l: Conrade can prattle ſomewhat, Sir, to that
Purpoſe.

sp.speaker: Conr.
sp.l: Good faith you do me wrong. I'ue worne, Sir,
A Ladies ſlipper in my hat, or ſo.
Frollo is the man that gets their Pendants,
Armelets, Rings, and all the Toyes of valew.

sp.speaker: Frollo.
sp.l: Excuſe me, ſir, not I. Signior Cunymond
Has all the voyce at Court. We know, Sir, when,
And where, a certaine Dutcheſſe, Sir;
You copulate with Titles, you.
The Heralds are your Bawds.

sp.speaker: Cuny.
sp.p: Hold! grow particular in ſuch a Theame as this!

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.p: Well, Gentlemen, I muſt be furniſh'd too.

sp.speaker: Cuny.
sp.p: With a Miſtreſſe?

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: Yes, inquire me out ſome old Land-Carack.
I am content to ſtretch my loynes for a
Penſion.

sp.speaker: Cuny.
sp.p: At what rate doe you valew your ſelfe?

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.p: I was neuer pawn'd, Sir.

sp.speaker: Cuny.
sp.p: How, Captaine!

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: In this leane age, we valew all things
According to the rate, they pawne for.

sp.speaker: Frollo.
sp.l: But we muſt know, how much you would receiue
In price of your actiuitie?

sp.speaker: Conrad.
sp.p: You muſt neuer ſtray after freſh paſture.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: Some eight; I, I, eight hundred Crownes a yeere will doe't.
I am deſirous of no more then will
Maintaine my Genet, and my Dwarfe.

sp.speaker: Cuny.
sp.l: Your excuſe procur'd, tis fit you now tell,
How farre in your defence I may ingage
My honour: is not your fleſh a little tainted!
Are you not vnwholſome?

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: O death, no; no, no, no! Do not thinke I haue
A conſcience ſo ill bred, to put my ſelfe
Vpon a Lady, when vnfit for the affaire.

sp.speaker: Cuny.
sp.l: Well, Captaine, now with your own eies ſuruay
Your limmes; what vſe can a Lady haue
Of you? To propagate the Cough o'th lungs?

sp.speaker: Frollo.
sp.p: Or beget Cripples, to people an Hoſpitall?

sp.speaker: Conrad.
sp.l: Or produce another Nation that may
Wage fierce battaile 'gainſt the Cranes?

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: Yet I can follow your bodies with rough
Motion, and not ſhed my limmes by the way—

sp.speaker: Cuny.
sp.p: I told ye, he'ld make a ieaſt on't.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: But I will kick ye in earneſt,—kick ye
For my exerciſe and warmth—till my toes
Grow crooked—

div.stage: Enter Valdaura, reading to her ſelfe, then Albouine, Hermegild.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.p: Purſue Valdaura, Sir.

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.p: I hate theſe Iiggeries.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: You know, I am materiall in my ſpeech,
Full of duty; you want the ſilken garbe,
That muſt indeere you to the Ladies eyes.

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.p: Yet I am louing in my drinke.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: Greet her kindly, Sir: tis Paradines Bride.
You haue not ſeene her ſince ſhe indeuour'd
To increaſe the number of your ſubiects,
With loſſe of her virginitie.

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.l: Rhodolinda doth ſo ingroſſe my loue,
That on other Ladies I'ue but little
To beſtow.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: Sir, practiſe but your Courtſhip here. In troth
You muſt affect the amorous Cringe, geſtures
Smooth and pliant; it will neuer doe elſe.
I'ue heard the Queene complaine, you are too rough:
And what theſe Ladies doe obſerue, will take
A ſudden flight vnto her eare. Strike but
Their ſences gently with your tongue. Often
Flatter'em, and with a vigorous breath;
They'll then implore the Queene in your behalfe:
And, Sir, th' indeuour of their praiſe will ſoone
Procure your peace.

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.l: If they would ſoften Rhodolinda's heart,
And reconcile me to her ſmiles, I would
Grow fond, and dally then with all the Sex.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: Begin your triall. If you ſalute this,
(And other Ladies too) with ſome impreſſion on
Their lipps; with managing their fingers thus,—
With ſeyſure on her wriſt; as if you had
Some buſineſſe with her Pulſe: then you inchant.
Be flexiue in your ſmiles, and wanton like,
Seeke pictures in their eyes: and when they moue,
Then with perſonall conduct, guide their feet.
'Mongſt them you cannot ſeeme too cheape. They will
Admire you for't, and ſing your prayſes to
The Queene.

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.p: I ſhall be taught to ſpin, and ſtarch!

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: The engin's now compact; each wheele doth moue
With ſilent ſcrewes. The Mole's the ſubtle Pioner:
For when ſhe vndermines the earth, her ſlow
Motion makes no noiſe. Exit.

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.l: Y'are deuout, Vauldaura. Teach me to pray:
We haue no leaſure for't in warre; and 't has
Been long time out of faſhion here in Court.

sp.speaker: Vald.
sp.l: I feare I make ſome breach of duty with
Your Excellence, to hinder thus
The paſſage of your Royall thoughts.

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.l: You teach me now, t'excuſe my owne abrupt
Demeanour; but I can doe't. My harſh Queene
(Whom the perſpicuous Eye of heauen forgiue)
Doth much miſtake the poſture of my limmes,
And geſture of my tongue among your Sex.
I neuer vſe, like rugged Polypheame,
To dandle Cubs. Thus, I can gently touch
A Ladies lips—yet make no battery on
Her teeth. Was it not an ayrie preſſure?
Tell my proud Queene, I'ue loſt my Iron garbe,
And now am growne thus fond and ſmooth.

sp.speaker: Vald.
sp.l: O Royall Sir, her cruelty hath put
My eyes vnto th'expence of many teares.

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.l: I, but in vaine! Thoſe clouds muſt weep apace,
That meane to penetrate the Marble, or
The Flint. I weare no Gauntlet on my hand,
Why ſhould you thinke that I would bruiſe
Your fingers with my touch— Sports with her hand.

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.p: Is this Paradines Garden?

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: I Madam, and your Excellence may finde
A ſudden growth, in all that ſhadowes vs.

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.p: Hah I looke there!

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.p: What is 't your eyes ſo eagerly diſcerne?

sp.speaker: Rho.
sp.l: The King! How ſportfull he is growne? how full
Of amarous game and dalliance?

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.p: I ſpie Valdaura there: but is that the King?

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.p: Thou doſt inquire, t'affront my ſight.

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.l: You muſt informe the Queene of this: Say, I
Am ſmooth, and muſicall, and trim, and that
I talke no more of warre, nor drinke.

sp.speaker: Vald.
sp.l: Tis my duty to vrge all circumſtance,
That may credit you in her eſteeme.

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.l: It is a piece of courtſhip to ſalute
At parting— Kiſſes her. exit Valdaura.

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.p: Is that a ſafe coniunction in ſo hot a climate!

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.l: Hell and death! VVhat raw diſcipline is this?
I ſhould conduct her in her way— Exit.

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.l: So violent in purſuit of your game?
Let's follow, Hermegild?

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: Not for all the Sunne beholds in's iourney
Through the world—

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.p: VVhy? be nimble in thy ſpeech!

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: It ſhewes but ſilly art in induſtry,
To ſeeke what you would not finde.

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.l: I pre thee grow particular! Doſt thinke
They purpoſe ought ith' darke? or, was this ſame
But ceremonious forme! ſuch a greeting
As courtſhip will admit in publike interuiew?

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: The King was neuer giuen to complement,
You know. As for Valdaura—

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.p: What of her?

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: I thinke that ſhe is chaſte, but—

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.l: Doe not inuolue thy language thus
In periods of ſuſpence.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: I wiſh the King had not deſeru'd to be
Depriu'd of your ſoft imbraces, then
He might haue kept his conſtitution tame.

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.p: O, is it ſo?

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: It ill becomes the garbe of Maieſty,
To run thus neighing (like a riotous Horſe)
After each female that he ſpies.

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.p: VVhy, does he vſe it?

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: Madam, you queſtion me, as if what I
Declare, were to your knowledge new and ſtrange.

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.p: By heauen and ſo it is.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: O my officious Soule! muſt it be my crime
To giue the information vp? would I
Had knowne the King was here, you ſhould haue made
Another path, your walke.

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.p: Hermegild, you did mis-ſpend that breath.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: Alas, you had enough of griefe before.
This addition will but ſhew a tyranny
In fate and me. It works with hight, like new
Mighty wine! as if 't would ſplit the Caske.

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.l: O periur'd, black, adulterous King! affront
My Fathers Ghoſt? Diſturbe his Aſhes in
His tombe? Whē drunk with pride, he mock'd me with
The gawdy title of a Queene, and now
I am become a ſtale for all his luſt.
Valdaura too! ſo pure of heart (forſooth)
That ſhe would bluſh to ſee her own hand, if nak'd:
They are proſcrib'd. Know, Hermegild,
Our Country ſhall be free.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: This is a noble rage! Heauen knowes how I
Haue grieu'd at your decay of ſoule. 'T was my
Sad feare, that all the angry ſparkes, which were
By Iuſtice kindled in your breſt, had been
Extinguiſh'd quite, now they grow vp in flames.
You now like Phoebus ſhew, when he hath waſh'd
His face with Dew. Your influence doth infuſe
A noble heate, ſuch as would motion giue
Vnto aged Statues; make them pluck vp
Their Moſſie feet, and walke.

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.l: Thou giu'ſt my ſences pride! What in this great
Buſineſſe wilt thou doe, t' incourage hope?

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: I will mingle poyſon in my Inke, write
VVith a Rauens Quill! 't will be a fatall
Scripture: and ſhall charme like to thoſe wiſe Iigs
The Syrens ſing. Some muſt direction beare
T' our Penſioners, that in our Country rule
The ſterne Edicts of Law: ſome to Martiall
Spirits, who with their able skill doe leade
Thoſe Regiments, the King hath gariſon'd
I'th bordering Townes. They ſhall reuolt, my Queene,
And ſeate thee in thy Fathers Chaire: they muſt
Be drunke with the Elixir of my Gold.

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.l: VVhen firſt I choſe thee out for this great work,
I ſaw thee thorow a Perſpectiue reuerſs'd;
For thou didſt ſeeme much leſſer then thou art.
Kneele, and be happy!—Before
The Genius of this place, and what is here
Immortall, I vow to aſſiſt with my
Moſt actiue skill, all thy deſignements 'gainſt
The King; and when my iuſt hopes are finiſh'd,
To be thy Wife. Such as doe periur'd prooue,
Lightning will ſurely clothe with ſubtle flames,
And they ſhall burne like glimmering Tapers
In darke hell: pale, and ſickly as that fire
The Ghoſt of Nero makes.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: This new ambition hath ſo exalted
All my faculties, that I ſeeme taller
Kneeling, then when I ſtood. But here with ſtrict
Solemnitie I vow to teach my Soule
New wayes of merit: to reuenge with ſterne,
And horrid wrath, the Kings proud tyranny.
To make your Greatneſſe abſolute, and high,
Or ſinke my ſelfe lower then a Plummet,
In the Baltick Sea. Should I not this performe,
The Starres would fall like Cinders on my head:
And winds impriſon'd in the Earth; breake forth,
In a wilde ruine, and ſhake me into ſand:
Then blow me in your Eyes; where if in teares
You drowne me, I am intomb'd in Pearle: and then
My obſequies requite my death.

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.l: Enough. I proffet to thy lip, the firſt
Taſte of my affection— They kiſſe, then riſe.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: 'T was moyſt and luſcious! I will cheriſh this
Indeerement. Trees that talleſt grow, doe take
The deepeſt roote; ſo I muſt firſt ſinke low
Ith' Earth; and after climbe to fathome clouds.
Firſt, praiſe her mimick laughter: when ſhe weepes,
Then gather vp with couetous regard
Her teares for ſcatter'd Pearle. Licke her ſpittle
From the ground: this diſguiz'd humilitie
Is both the ſwift, and ſafeſt way to pride—

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.l: Sure, Hermegild, I haue amaz'd thy ſence,
Thou look'ſt like ſome ore-growne Fiend, chain'd vp
Within a ſilent caue. Let vs retire, and Ile
Diſcouer how I'ue practis'd my reuenge.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: I proiect to make you mighty! You ſhall
Aſcend my beautious Soueraigne, till you
Can reach the Moone, and pick thoſe ſeeds of light
(The leſſer Stars) from forth their wandring Spheares;
To weare as new imbroadery on your ſleeue.
I long to heare your fatall Arts. Let's mix
Our ſences, and contriue. A womans will,
Is not ſo ſtrong in anger, as her skill.

div.stage: Enter Paradine, a Gentleman and Page.

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.p: You bring no letters from Cracouia, Sir?

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: None, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.p: Nor from Sienna?

sp.speaker: Gentlem.
sp.l: Your Lordſhip in thoſe few, receiues th'intire
Purpoſe of my iourney.

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: Alas, my Countrymen! Captiuitie
Is hoarce, they haue more griefs then tongue: they ſpeak
Not loud enough to wake the eare of heauen.
Henceforth to Hermegild bid them direct
Their ſighs; for I'm ſo dull, ſo weary, and
Neglectfull of ambitious ends, that I
Shall loſe my ſtrength, and fauour with the King.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: My noble Lord, our prayers will ouer-rule that prophecy.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: You may expect, whilſt I am able to
Performe. Boy, beſpeake the Gentleman a free
And bounteous welcome. Sir, I will haſten
Your diſpatch.

sp.speaker: Theſ.
sp.p: My Lord; I haue tyr'd my ſelfe in your ſearch.

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: The faire Theſina? You are rarely here
A viſitant! Where haue you left my Bride?

sp.speaker: Theſ.
sp.l: With the Queene, my Lord, who is ſo fond
Of her attendance, ſhe'le ſcarce allow her ſpace
To winke in her owne ſeruice, and to night
She lyes within her chamber.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Hah! ſo ſoone deuided! Th'approching night
Should helpe to ſecond our imbraces.

sp.speaker: Theſ.
sp.l: Y'are now to truſt my Art. For Valdaura
Sent me t'expreſſe her ioy, i'th deliuery
Of this meſſage. You ſhall lye with her to night.

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: How can my faith admit of this, ſince ſhe
Is billited where the Queene ſleepes?

sp.speaker: Theſ.
sp.l: Ile perfect my aſſurance; ſo you'll pleaſe
T'obey what I inioyne. When you approach
The Spheare, where your bright Phoebe rules, doe not
Occaſion ſo much noyſe, as ſhall expreſſe
You liuing. You muſt not ſpeake to her, nor
By your geſtures, inuite her ſpeech. All this
Performe, leſt you ſhould wake the Queene.

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: To be dumbe in copulation! This is
A fine receipt to get a ſilent Girle.
But I ſhall prooue obedient.

sp.speaker: Theſ.
sp.l: And (Sir) as y' are mercifull to Ladies
(Ripe in growth) doe not breathe too loud, leſt we
Ith' neighbouring roome, ore-heare the harmony,
And ſinne in wiſhes.

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.p: Feare not, Theſina: I ſhall be temperate.

sp.speaker: Theſ.
sp.l: But you young ſouldiers are ſo boyſterous,
You'll thinke anon, y'are battering ſome Towne-wall.
Follow, Sir, Ile direct ye to the place,
Where, when the darke howre arriues, you muſt
Addreſſe your viſit.

div.head: Act the fourth. Scene firſt.

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: The early Lark climbes higher then his voice;
And whiſpers into Phoebus eare, a glad
Welcome; who ſmiles, and ſeemes to prophecy
A gawdy day. Valdaura? Madame? ſpeake,
Sweet Lady! or, if for concealement of
Our ſtolne rapture you ſilence ſtill aſſume;
Yet riſe, and bleſſe my eye-ſight with thy faire
Preſence. Come, and eclipſe the enuious day!
Not talke ith' buſineſſe, nor yet behold
The ground we till, as if we both were blinde
And dumbe. Ile no more by ſtealth ingender;
Cripples are got thus. Kind Valdaura, ſpeake!
sp.stage: A hand is thruſt out betweene the Arras.
sp.l: See, a new day breakes in her hand! Theſe are
The roſie fingers of the Morne!
Hah! the Queene! Valdaura! Bride, where art thou?

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.l: In vaine thou call'ſt. The Cannons Iron throat,
Although high mounted on you' Pinacle,
Scarce could reach her eare. She's in Pauia now,
Two Leagues ſituate from hence.

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.p: Thou art myſterious as an Oracle!

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.l: I ſent her thither, with pretence ſhe ſhould
Suruay the modell of a Garden-worke.
But 'twas done, that Theſina might intice
With apter leaſure, thy perſon to my bed.
At noone thy wife returnes.

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: I'ue miſtaken then my warme embraces,
And ſinn'd with thee th' adulterous Queene!

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.l: Thou haſt inioy'd what Albouine with all
His Royall ſighs, his teares ſwolne bigger then
His eyes, deſpair'd to merit.

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: O horror! gape, rugged Earth! Suck me in
Like ſome old Pyramid, whoſe ponderous limmes
Haue been thy burden ſince the Flood, and now
Their owne foundation ſinke. Could you make
No choice to quench your rauenous luſt, but me?
Where were the broad-chin'd Zwitzers of your Guard?

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.l: This (Paradine) denotes a melting braine:
Which out of vulgar pity I forgiue.
'Twas not the wanton taſte of thy ſmooth limmes,
That could prouoke me vſe this ſtratagem.
But loue of my reuenge. I'ue ſtrongly now
Ingag'd thy power, to kill the King.

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.p: Hah!

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.l: Which do: and ere the Sun arriue ith'Weſt;
Or with diſheuell'd haire, my veſtments torne
(As if I'd wandred thorow ſome Hathorne hedge)
I will approach the Tyrant, acquaint him
With this deed, and call my owne adultery
Thy fowle rape.

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: Who 's within there, hoa! My Hogs-head's empty.
I was not borne with ſo much braines, as would
Bedew a clout, that my cold Noſthrill ſtopt.
Theſe Court ſmocks containe the very Deuill.
Good heauen! how leane ſhould I haue made my heart
With ſtudious thoughts, ere I the skill had reach'd
Of ſuch a damn'd proiection.

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.l: Collect thy ſcatter'd thoughts. What thy reſpect
To thy captiu'd Country, could ne're charme thee
To reuenge; be prompted to, by a kinde
Affection of thy owne deare life: reuenge
Vpon a Tyrant; One, that loues not me,
Nor thee; vnleſſe in ſpeech: he hath a ſmooth
Tongue, but a rugged heart. My Hermegild
Perceiues this truth, and can deliuer it
With all the pride of knowledge.

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: Sure Time growes humerous with age: for things
Doe differ much from the ſincereneſſe of
Their firſt creation. I will goe weepe
Till I am blind—

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.l: Stay, Paradine. If thou doſt mocke my hopes
With a ſlow motion in this iuſt deſigne,
Expect to finde my anger fatall. Ile to
The King, and make a forfeiture of both
Our liues: but if with hardy ſinnewes thou doſt march
To 's Throat, and ſlit the ſwarthy Pipe, I'le call
Thee then my Souldier. Beſides thy Countries thanks,
Thou ſhalt enioy me for thy Queene, thy Wife,

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: New Arts, t'inuolue imagination!
How can this be, and my owne wife ſtrongly
Poſſeſs'd of health and nature!

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.l: VVould'ſt thou imbrace ſo eminent a bliſſe,
VVithout ſome danger to thy ſoule?

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: My memory betrayes my skill! I know
There are a thouſand wayes to diſcard her,
From this foule, durty Orbe.

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.l: Alas, good eaſie Soule! She'le ne're be miſs'd
Among the liuing. Know, Valdaura's falſe.

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.p: How! Falſe!

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.l: She is a open whore, and hath taught me
This Art of luſt.

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: More horrible then Hell!
Now furniſh but my hands with an Hower-glaſſe,
And a long Dart, then ſeat me on ſome rotten
Monument for the picture of leane Death.
Make me the common Executioner
Of Nature. For ere long I ſhall become
The Sextons Penſioner to fill his Graues.
Valdaura falſe!

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.l: Wilt thou thus leaue me in a wilde ſuſpence,
Whether I ſhall finde thy courage actiue?

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: For credit of your owne humanitie,
Doe not infringe the vulgar priuiledge
Due to all hearts. Giue me but leaue to thinke;
And ne're doubt your buſineſſe! Though I'm a young
Sinner; yet I ſhall ſoone inquire the way
To hell. Tis a continu'd thorow-fare
From this Climate thither. Or let me but
Delay my iourney, till the triuiall rage
Of Chriſtian Princes, meete in horri'd battaile;
And then I ſhall haue company enough:
VVhole throngs to choke the throat of hell.
Good night, Madame.

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.l: Ere yet the Morne 's faire cheek hath loſt her teares,
Doſt call it night?

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: To me it ſeemes the Eye of heauen doth winke.
All things are cloath'd in darkeneſſe, blacke as your
Deſigne.

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.l: Stay, for elſe my rage will not permit
That we ſuruiue another meeting.
If thou ſuſpectſt we are too loud, I will
Diſtill my thoughts into thy eare.

div.stage: She hangs about his necke whiſpering.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: Though t'aſſiſt my great hopes with opportune
Induction, I conſented to this act:
Yet now I chide my fond ſpirits. For who
Dares truſt th' vnruly appetite of youth?
What I decreed ſhe ſhould but taſte, ſhe may
Delight to ſurfeit on. It ſhewes fulſome!
Here's the precious medicine that muſt reſtore
Health to my hopes. Follow, gentle Lady.
You ſee 'em now?

sp.speaker: Vald.
sp.l: Fall, fall, you thicke and ſpungy clouds, vntill
You choke my ſight. Doe not my eyes begin
To bleed at this obiect?

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: Marke how cloſe they meete: what variety
They vſe in luſt: now ſhe hath melted quite his lips
With her hot breath, ſhe hangs vpon his eare.
Suruay their geſtures ſtill. Now they depart.

sp.speaker: Vald.
sp.l: Ile ſummon all the hierarchy of heauen
To cenſure'em!

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: VVho knowes but they are gone to wallow in
Their actiue ſweats agen? Alas, pure ſoule!
You perceiue theſe figures no Idea,
No obiect of the minde, or ayre incorporate
To cheate imaginary view.

sp.speaker: Vald.
sp.l: Was this the cauſe, that made th'adulterous Queene
So ſtrictly vrge my ſwift iourney vnto
Pauia?

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: I, and the motiue that prouok'd my ſoft
Conſcience to haſten your returne, that you
Might tell ſad tales to heauen. For I
(That ſtill was nourc'd vpon a Sybils Lap)
Who with prophetick Milke did nouriſh me,
Can deepely gueſſe at th'ominous portent
Of ſinne. I hate ſuch looſe-rein'd Stallions;
Such laſciuious harmony in guilt.

sp.speaker: Vald.
sp.l: So ſoone proue falſe? ere the celebration
Of our marriage Rites were fully ended?
Ere the Sunne in's iourney o're this Region
Had twice beheld thus incorporate
By holy Church, and ſmil'd vpon the hopes
Of our increaſe?

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: I, there's a contemplation that would crack
Euen heart-ſtrings made of wyer. Hymens Taper
But newly lighted, and he with rude breath
Blowes from the quickning weeke the gawdy flame.
Then in the darke, thus wilfully miſſe-takes
