Your bed, and riots 'tweene vnlawfull ſheets.
Horror! horror!

sp.speaker: Vald.
sp.l: O my ſiniſter Starres! Thus I ſhall weepe
Till I haue emptied all my veines.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: What ſhould ſuch white and harmeleſſe ſoules as we
Do crawling o're this mountainous Earth? Alas,
We cannot drinke, till we intoxicate
A Whale, nor ſurfeit, till our greazie cheekes
Doe ſwell like Th'vdders of a Cow. Nor can
We kneele like warme Idolaters, vnto
The ruſty metall in a bag. We want
Theſe helpes to gaine vs honour and eſteeme.

sp.speaker: Vald.
sp.l: I haue a reſolute intent to die,
And ſeeke my Manſion in a purer Orbe.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: But ere you doe begin your laſt walke, ith' path
Inuiſible, ſome meritorious act
(Ioynd to the Charter of your Creed) ſhould helpe
T'aſſure your future bliſſe.

sp.speaker: Vald.
sp.l: O name it, ere my ſorrow ſhall decay
Me ſtrength: for I would mix abilitie
With will.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: Your Lord (foule, and ſinfull as mortalitie
Can make him) Salamander-like, ſhall bathe
In blue fires, vnleſſe by ſufferance here
On earth, he penetrate the hearth of heauen,
And ſoften their decree. It will be call'd
Your merit to reuenge his crime, euen with his death.

sp.speaker: Vald.
sp.l: Would you haue me kill him?

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: Since I am ſtrict to vertue, I muſt needs
Be cruell vnto vice. Let him not liue
To increaſe his owne guilt, and betray more
Ladies.

sp.speaker: Vald.
sp.l: But ſhall I iuſtice take from powerfull Heauen,
And vſe it with ſuch cruelty?

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: Beleeue me skill in ſacred Oracles,
My piety to warrant the deſigne
Nor will I fright the frailty of your Sex,
With horrid circumſtance; he ſhall not bleed,
This Violl doth containe a draught; which if
In's vſuall Beueridge powr'd, will coozen him
Of's leprous ſoule in his moſt quiet ſleepe.

sp.speaker: Vald.
sp.l: I doe ſuſpect my courage!

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: Tak't, faire Pupill! think on't in your prayers.
If you but enioy one ſingle motion
That informes you it is good: do't with pride
And boldneſſe maſculine. Diſtinguiſh thus
Its operation. Foure dayes muſt fully take
Their room ith'Kalendar, ere it effect
Our hopes. Before that houre ariue, he muſt
Be wrought to kill the King.

sp.speaker: Vald.
sp.l: The Violl liquid Lead containes, or elſe
Some farre more ponderous Metall: for whilſt
I beare it thus, the wieght ſeemes to infuſe
A Palſey in my hand. I tremble like
A ſtring touch'd on my Lute.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: It is the Fiend, that would dehort you from
A pious act: truſt not his whiſpring charmes
But with a hardy courage, (more then is
Naturall in thy modeſt Sex) proceed
To merit heauen. And now requite my forward zeale
To vertue, with concealement of my name,
And intereſt in this act. Let not the Queene
Nor your falſe Lord, know me the Perſpectiue,
Through which you ſaw their rauenous luſts, but ſay,
The King reueal'd it to your eare. 'Twill make
Them wilde, and doubt their owne confedrate Bawds.
Thinke not I forbid it as a danger
To my perſon; for I affect not life.
So ſoft and eaſie-metald is my heart,
So well I loue your ſinfull Lord, that when
I heare the ſurly Bell proclaime his death,
Like ſome new weand Babe, I ſhall dye crying.

sp.speaker: Vald.
sp.l: Would you haue him kill'd, yet loue him thus?

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: I, but I loue heauen better. Where, when
I come, troth I ſhall prooue too fond a Saint.
Thoſe Votaries that pray to me, ſhall finde
Their buſineſſe ſoone diſpatch'd: here, let this key
Obſcure ye in my Clozet vntill noone:
For then the Queene expects you will return
From Pauia. Farewell, the moſt abus'd,
But nobleſt Lady in the world.

div.stage: Enter Grimold (in an old rug gowne, muffled with cloutes) Gondibert, Vollterri.

sp.speaker: Gond.
sp.l: This is the priuy Gallery: place the Chaire,
Vollterri, where it needs muſt interrupt
The Kings paſſage.

sp.speaker: Vollt.
sp.l: If thy diſguize ſhould faile vs, Gondibert
And I muſt be attach'd for Impoſtors.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: And then be crop-card too, like Iriſh Nags.
You'le both prooue fleete in a Race, prouided
The foe charge ye in the Rere. Seate me with
Tender motion— This luxurious Citie
Hath made me ſo rotten, I dare not walke
Ith'winde, leſt I ſhould be blowne in pieces.

sp.speaker: Gond.
sp.l: Quick now counterfeit! Here comes Hermegild. Grimold groanes.
Groane out like a Bore.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.p: Who ownes that ſicke clamor?

sp.speaker: Gond.
sp.l: One (Sir) preſented here to tempt compaſſion
From all charitable eyes.

sp.speaker: Vollt.
sp.l: Want hath betray'd him to hunger, hunger
To this diſeaſe.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.p: O, O, O, the Crampe! the Crampe!

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.p: Where, Sir?

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.p: In my ſtomacke.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.p: That's indeed a cleere ſymptome of famine.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: I'ue eaten nothing this moneth but raw ayre,
And that giues but weake nouriſhment to age.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: It is my wonder, in a State ſo rich
As ours, a climate ſtill befriended thus
By nature (flouriſhing with hopefull Springs,
And Summers chok'd with wealth) a Souldier ſhould
Be forc'd to make his hunger a diſeaſe.
A prodigie vnparaleld, that want
Should e're occaſion ſuch a dangerous faſt.
Waſt not deuotion made him thus abſtaine
From meate?

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: Pure want, Sir, I know ſmall deuotion, I.
For though I faſt much, I pray as little
As moſt Chriſtians of my Calling. Groanes agen.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: He muſt be ſent vnto ſome Hoſpitall,
There eate warmth broths, till he recouer health:
And then I will procure him from the State
Some thrifty penſion, to maintaine the ſhort
Remainder of his life in ſober works.
He ſhall ſing Hymnes, and pray to the kind Saints
In a blue gowne.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: Alas, Sir, I am growne ſo hoarce, the Saints
Can hardly heare my Orizons.

sp.speaker: Gond.
sp.l: He will prooue (my Lord) a chargeable Cure:
For the Phyſicions do preſcribe him nought
For med'cine, but Aurum-Palpabile.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: The Elixir of Gold would ſurely much
Aſſwage the griefe in my ſtomacke— Groanes.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: He muſt needs be hungry, that like th'Oſtridge
Can digeſt Metall.

sp.speaker: Vollt.
sp.l: The King for his laſt ſeruices remaines
His debtor ſixe thouſand Duckats. My Lord,
You ſhall expreſſe much charity, if you
Procure it in a ſudden payment. The ſame will
Defray his ſickneſſe charge, and maintaine him
Well in's health.

sp.speaker: Gond.
sp.l: Your Lordſhip ſhall ingage vs then to drowne
Your chiefe Title in the beſt Grape. Wee'le drinke
Your health, vntill we raiſe the price of wine.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: Let him continue there his ſeate. Perhaps
They (whom I ſhall ſtraight conduct this way)
Will ſo commiſerate his want, that he
Will ſoone relieue't, though he increaſe his owne.
There is ſome Arte in this, which I muſt needs
Diſcouer, or forfeit my paines. Exit.

sp.speaker: Gond.
sp.p: The Fiend is gone!

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: Will all the vaſt accruements I proiect
From this diſguize, conuert into
The ſlender purchaſe of an Hoſpitall?

sp.speaker: Vollt.
sp.p: Thou turne Votary?

sp.speaker: Gond.
sp.l: He'le pray in no language but the High-Dutch,
The angry Tongue, which ſeemes to threaten more,
Then implore.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: Six thouſand Duckats for a Manſion in
An hoſpitall, no bigger then a coffin:
Where like Carthuſians, we muſt feed, not to
Preuent hunger, but to hinder luſt. Princes
May eaſily pay their debts, when they inforce
Their Creditors to buy Titles and Place
At their owne rates.

sp.speaker: Vollt.
sp.l: Harke! there's ſomebody approaching hither.
Tis no ſafe game to ſport with Kings. I'le be gon.

sp.speaker: Gond.
sp.l: Grimold, now truſt to your owne performance,
I may haue vſe for my eares, I would not
Yet leaue them in the Pillory.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: Gondibert, Vollterri! forſake the ſtorme
Ere ye are wet? Weezels! Monkeys! Dogs!

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: Madame, you are now fully ſatisfied
Ith'intention of this viſit. I wiſh
You'ld be as free, and ſportiue with him, as
Your modeſty will giue you leaue.

sp.speaker: Theſ.
sp.p: Truſt my obedience, and my skill, Sir.

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.p: He lookes like a watchman in that Rugge.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: Your Maieſty receiues new cauſe to doubt
The truth of his diſeaſe, from my Seruants
Information. Who ſweares, this very Morne
Hee hath been ſeene in all the violence
Of drinke, and ith' Burdelli too. For, Sir,
Though he be old, he's giuen much to propagation.

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.l: Let vs retire 'tweene th'Arras, and we
Shall ſhare, ith'whole diſcouery. He groanes.

sp.speaker: Theſ.
sp.l: Alas, who is't, that ſo prouokes the tongue
Of pitty!

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: An old ſouldier o' the Kings—

sp.speaker: Theſ.
sp.l: Hah! Captaine Grimold! how come you thus
Impriſon'd in a Chaire? haue you the Gowte?

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.p: I am not rich enough t'inioy the Gowte.

sp.speaker: Theſ.
sp.p: What name then doe you giue to your diſeaſe!

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.p: The Phyſicions call it famine.

sp.speaker: Theſ.
sp.l: How? Heauen ſecure the State! I hope we are
Not guilty of a ſinne ſo horrible,
To deny a Souldier fit materials
For conſeruation of his life.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: Tis fourteene dayes ſince I haue had a iuſt
Occaſion but to picke my teeth.

sp.speaker: Theſ.
sp.p: Alas the day!

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: Each of my thighes are dry'd, and hardned like
An old Weſt-Falia Flitch. All m'interals
Are ſhrunke vp. My bladder is no bigger then
A Pigs: and were my leane iawes vnmuffled,
You ſhould ſee me mumpe, like a Matrone that
Had loſt her teeth.

sp.p: O cruell ſtarres! —

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.p: Hah! Does ſhe weepe?

sp.speaker: Theſ.
sp.l: Could you on this wide Earth, finde no obiect
For your fury, but braue Grimold? Or is't
Becauſe you ſaw, it was my chiefe vertue
To affect a Souldier?

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.p: If ſhe ſhould be in earneſt now?

sp.speaker: Theſ.
sp.p: I hope you doe not vtterly deſpaire of life?

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: I may linger out a ſcore of yeeres, or ſo;
But I cannot liue long.

sp.speaker: Theſ.
sp.l: Since you are mark'd for ſudden death, cold death
That ſilenceth all tongues: and ſince this place
Is ſo ſecure from neighbouring eares, I will
Diſcloſe, what vntill now my modeſty
Inforc'd me to conceale.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.p: I ſhall forget to counterfeit!

sp.speaker: Theſ.
sp.l: Know, Sir, that I haue lou'd you long; lou'd you
With ſoft and tender paſſion.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: O Rogue! VVhat doe I like the picture
Of VVinter, in this wither'd habit? I muſt
Recouer my health. But alas, Madame,
Doe not deride his deſtiny, that now
Is taking flight to reach that place, where your
Beſt Starre inhabits, and ſhall haue power
To tell loud tales: if you prooue thus cruell.
How could you e're loue me? I haue been old,
Euen ſince your firſt originall growth.

sp.speaker: Theſ.
sp.l: But if you will permit, I may expreſſe
A little vanity in loue, I can
Informe you, Sir, how much we Ladies prize
Age before Youth in Louers. Old men are
Diſcreet ſinners, and offend with ſilence.
But young men, when the game is done, doe crow
Like pregnant Cocks: boaſt to the world their ſtrength
In folly. Beſides (Sir) an authentick
Lady ſayes in her Problemes thus:
The Young and ſlender Graft is eaſly broke,
But who can ſhake, or bruiſe the aged Oke?

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.p: A rare Adage.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.p: The Lady Author ſure, is o'th'Moddernes.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: My ioy is turn'd to a diſeaſe; it makes
Me ſpeechleſſe! I euer thought theſe Court-Tits
Were much taken with my ſmooth lookes; but that
Their modeſty ſtill kept them from my reach.
Fooliſh modeſty! It has hindred my
Preferment much for ſince I left the Campe,
I haue been in loue with ſome three hundred
Of'em, yet neuer durſt lay claime to one.
Vh! vh! If Heauen ſhould ſo affect
Our mutuall appetites, as to reſtore
My health, would you continue ſtill to doate
Vpon an old ſinner?

sp.speaker: Theſ.
sp.l: O, I ſhould grow more fond; preſerue you long
Aliue with zealous Orizons!

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: Las! poore Maulkin! She's caught! I ſhall grow rich.
For I haue heard, theſe Court-Ladies allow
Large penſions to their Paramors. Helpe! helpe!
To mooue me higher in my ſeate—

div.stage: She takes him by the hand, he riſes.

sp.speaker: Theſ.
sp.l: Bleſſe vs! me thinks, Sir, you begin to vſe
Your legges with actiue ſtrength.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.p: A precious Ape!

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.p: He will ſhew fine tricks anon!

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: Some ſtrange influence from your touch, hath giuen
A ſecond Youth vnto my faculties:
Before, I ſeem'd to crawle like to a Crab:
Now my ioynts grow ſupple, as if I were
Prouided for a Race. This hand inſpires my ſtrength—

sp.speaker: Cuny.
sp.p: I haue a Key, will giue vs paſſage here to th'Park!

sp.speaker: Theſ.
sp.l: Vnhand me, Sir, for I ſhall forfeit all
My fame elſe. They'll thinke, I am immodeſt—

div.stage: He ſpies them, then drops downe in's Chaire.

sp.speaker: Conrad.
sp.p: Captaine Grimold!

sp.speaker: Frollo.
sp.p: He ſits like a Witch, ſayling in a ſiue.

sp.speaker: Cuny.
sp.l: Hah! ſicke! Gentlemen, auoid the windy ſide,
Leſt he infect ye with his breath. I know
His diſeaſe, and whence it came, ſhortly
You'le ſee him weare a Curtaine ſore his Noſe;
That's now the neweſt faſhion that came from Paris.

sp.speaker: Frollo.
sp.l: I, tis it: he has them growing on his
Temples here—They'll ſhortly be as bigge
As Turnips.

sp.speaker: Conrad.
sp.l: He muſt to Roterdam, to the fat Doctor there,
And be ſtew'd in a Stoue, vntill he ſpit
His venome out.

sp.speaker: Cuny.
sp.l: And whilſt you are in phyſick (Captaine)
You fare like Oberon. Tis a very
Slender diet. The leane thigh of a Waſpe
To dinner; and ſome two or three of your
Owne penitent teares for your beueridge.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: I'ue but ſo much breath left, as would make vp
A ſhort prayer to ſecure my laſt iaunt:
Yet I will ſpend it in a hearty curſe
For your deare ſakes.

sp.speaker: Cuny.
sp.l: March on! If he doe finde himſelfe agrieu'd,
Let him ſend me a challenge after his death;
And I will meete him, Ith' Elizian Fields.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.p: I will eate that Cunymond!

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.p: How prompt the Slaue is, in 's metamorphoſis?

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.p: To him agen, Madame?

sp.speaker: Theſ.
sp.l: Alas, deare Captaine, what bodily hope
Can a young Lady haue of your performance,
That fall ſo ſoone in a relapſe?

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: When you depriu'd me of your hand, you took
Away my ſtrength and heate: touch me agen,
And I ſhall walke ſtiffe as Cacus. She lifts him vp.

sp.speaker: Theſ.
sp.p: Take leaſure in your motion, Sir.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: Looke, Madame. I creepe as other mortall do,
On the ſurface of the Earth—

sp.speaker: Theſ.
sp.p: Me thinks you ſtand vpright too.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: I, a Ladies warme hand will make it ſtand.
A little phyſicke from your Lip, and then
My cure is quite finiſh'd — Hem! Sure this was
Neſtors receipt to recouer his Youth. Hem!—

sp.speaker: Theſ.
sp.p: I ſhall be fainted for this miracle.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: I am as wholeſome as a Nut, and haue
As proud fleſh about me, as the youngeſt
Gameſter of 'em all.

sp.speaker: Theſ.
sp.p: Fye, Sir!

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: If this heate continue, I muſt e'en call
For a Iulip, or ſow my wilde Oates
In the next ſoyle I meete.

sp.speaker: Theſ.
sp.p: Your tongue is bliſter'd▪

sp.speaker: Grimo.
sp.p: When ſhall we ſolace our bodies?

sp.speaker: Theſ.
sp.p: Your meaning, Sir?

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: I meane ith' darke. Speak, prety Finch with the
Greene taile? Hah! Muſt we kiſſe cloſe, and often?
Wriggle vp and downe like young Eeles—

div.stage: Hermegild comes behind him, and puls him by the arme.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: Captaine, I haue brought the King here to view,
And to commiſerate your leane ſickneſſe,
And your feeble wants.

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.p: Thou old rauenous Goate!

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: He lookes now like an Alchymiſt, that is
Broyling o'red Herrings.

sp.speaker: Theſ.
sp.l: Or like the brazen head, when 'twas about
To ſpeake— He takes the King aſide.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.p: You meane to hang me now!

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.p: Haſt thou deſeru'd an eaſier ſentence?

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: When I am dead, then all my debts are pay'd.
For I leaue ſmall Lands and Chattels behind me.
But hearke ye (my Liege) you may pay your debts
In your life time, ſo depriue your Executor
Of a trouble.

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.l: O what a triuiall exit ſhall I make
From my owne world? for when I die, I die
For loue.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: And I for lechery. Sir, I would faine
Depart in quiet like other young Chryſomes:
Faine make all euen betweene the world and me.
I beſeech your Highneſſe diſcharge my areres
For my laſt ſeruice in Hungary,
Then hang me when you pleaſe.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: Captaine, I will be a Sutor for your reprieue.
You ſhall onely forfeit what his Grace owes you;
And then your life's ſecur'd.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: I will rather die twice. O Sir▪ pay me
Six thouſand Duckats, and then proclaime
Your ſentence here aloud. I would faine dye
Merrily. I haue not been drunke at my owne charge
This foure moneths.

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.l: Hermegild, iterate now thy ſweete raptures.
Speake to her; for, by th' gentle carriage of
Her eyes, I doe perceiue ſhe 'gins to penetrate.

sp.speaker: Theſ.
sp.l: Away Captaine! be gone whilſt you are yet
Mortall. I haue much power with Hermegild,
And will vpon your patient ſufferance
Redeeme my credit with your thoughts. Quick then,
Mooue with ſilence.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: Madame, the feather'd Arrow ſings ith' Ayre,
Ere it ariue where it muſt wound; ſo this
Sweet harmony, I 'ld haue you counterfeit,
But tempts him to ſecurity in ſleepe,
Before his death.

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.p: I'm much oblig'd to that good ſoule.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: True, my Royall Lady! yet now peruſe
The greatneſſe of his being▪ his fate in battailes,
And by your owne remembrance be inform'd
Of our captiuitie.

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.p: Honeſt Hermegild?

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.l: He was too cruell to a nature ſo
Remiſſe, and timorous as mine?

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: Alas, this crime he expiats with ſighs
So hot, that they would ſindge his Royall Beard,
Did not his numerous teares opportunely drop,
To quench the flame.

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.p: That's complement!

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: Theſe angry frownes vpon your browes make you
Appeare aged.

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.l: Could I aſſure my heart; he would no more
Triumph o're my deare Fathers memory;
I then ſhould meet his loue with too much paſſion.

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.l: When I am more my Chronicle, or ſpeake
My deeds with pride, may my tongue bliſter, till't
Infect my breath with Epidemick-heate.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: You heare his vowes?—Seeme fond. If you can ſhead
A teare, or two, the more to credit this
Atonement, 'twill much aduantage our pretence.
Sir, now enioy what your indulgent griefe
Merits to keepe, e'en from the hands of death.
Good heart, ſee how ſhee weepes?

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.l: I'm ſoone o'recome in this ſoft warre. S'death all
Can thaw but I. I neuer wept, but when
Th'vnruly winde blew in my eyes; and tis
No argument for ſterne battaile: elſe I
Would fight. To teſtifie the ioy my ſoule
Conceiues, Ile drinke—

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: Sir, you neglect to vſe her like a Louer;
With amorous geſtures.

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.l: Fill me a Bowle with Negro's blood, congeal'd
Euen into Liuers! Tell her, Hermegild,
Ile ſwallow Tarre, to celebrate her health!

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: Sir, this dull Germane phraſe, makes her ſuſpect
Your temperance. Marke how ſhe trembles.

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.l: I muſt go learne to complement. Doſt heare?
Is't fit I proffer her to mingle limmes—Thou know'ſt—

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: Sir, not to night. That was a ſerious ſute
She bade me make, when firſt ſhe purpos'd this
Atonement.

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.l: I do obey. Though I haue thoughts would faine
Perſwade me to rebellion.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: This was a ſubtill caution! elſe my hopes
Had twice been Cuckolded. Let'em reuell
With their ſalt Lippes. Th' other ſport is fulſome.
But Paradine diſturbes my ſleepe: he's young,
Enrich'd with all the fertill ſtrength of nature:
And needs muſt prooue more riotous in ſinne,
Then I. My darke practice, and vſe
Of ſilent contemplation; has made
My marrow thinne and black; like Inke within
My bones. I want the prompt alacrity. The Queene
Hath taſted him, and may (perhaps) ſtill to
Poſſeſſe his luſt; remooue Valdaura from
This foggy Soyle; then make him Lord of all
My hopes. This to preuent, I haue decreed,
Valdaura firſt ſhall miniſter his death.
I u'e taught her too; t' inſinnuate to his Creede,
That the King told her of 's adulterous luſt;
Good, for whē he thinks the King doth know that guilt,
His owne ſafety then, will ſoone prouoke him
Haſten our prodigious murther. This may
Be done, before the Poyſon operate
In dire effect; for that delays its power;
Till foureſcore houres expire their courſe: which then
No Antidote, nor humane skill reſiſts.
Mount, mount my thoughts, that I may tread on Kings,
Or if I chance to fall, thus ſoaring high;
I melt like Icarus, in the Sunnes Eye. Exit.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: The Sun doth melt vs with his ſcorching beames.
Goe fill my vſuall Beuiridge: Ile drinke
Till I am cold. Exit Page.
The conſtitution of my Soule, agrees
Not with this Climate. I grow weary
Of mortalitie. Euen in my firſt growth
(Since my Corſelet was my loade) I haue tooke
My breeding in the Campe; where had I ſtill
Remain'd a dull practike ſouldier, and nere ſeene
A Woman, nor the Court, I might haue had
Some hope, to gaine by faith, but now I reach
At wilde deſpaire. Enter Page with a Bowle.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.l: My Lady, Sir, commends her loue, and this
To your acceptance; ſhe made the mixture
With her owne hands.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: The Queene preſcrib'd this houre for her returne.
That ſhe growes black with ſinne, peruerts my ſenſe,
I muſt ſeem not to know't. Say, I greet her health-drinks.

div.stage: Exit Page. Enter Valdaura in cloſe mourning.

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: Hah! why, Valdaura, doſt thou appeare like
A funerall night, in darke, and ſwarthy weedes!

sp.speaker: Valdau.
sp.l: I mourne for you, ſince you muſt haſten your
Eternall abſence now from me, and all
That elſe are mortall.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Speak things, that are leſſe dangerous to my ſenſe.
This wonder will diſtract me.

sp.speaker: Vald.
sp.l: Ere winged Time, ſhall with ſwift motion adde
Another houre, to th' life of this ſicke day;
Thou ſhalt begin thy laſt ſleepe.

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: A pale Swanne hath ſung my Dirge! O fatall
Muſick! but how comes this intelligence
To Eares of fleſh and blood? haue you of late
Been goſſiping with the grim Stygian Dames,
And ſeene their Ciſers gall my vitall Thread?
For to my owne ſenſe I need no Phyſicke.
My faculties enioy that pleaſant ſtrength
Which appertaines to youth and temperance;
Why ſhould I yet die?

sp.speaker: Vald.
sp.l: How, Paradine? Art thou ſo full of guilt,
(Moſt vlcerous and deform'd) yet thinkſt to keepe
Thy life at Natures charge, t' exiſt till age
Makes thee a Cripple: then in thy bed,
(Like ſome good old Patriarke) thy ſoule diſmiſſe
With a diuine rapture? No, no; iuſt Heauen
Prouides more raſh and horrid deaths for ſuch,
As in adultery bathe their ſilken limmes.

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.p: Hah!

sp.speaker: Vald.
sp.l: I know thy guilt; the King hath told me all.
'Twas wondrous ſtrange! Our vowes but new arriu'd
In heauen, that did obliege our mutuall Faiths
In loue: and thou with ſauage luſt to breake them?
Though griefe hath much conſum'd my teares, yet I
Haue ſome ſtill left t' expreſſe my pitty.

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: My adultery already knowne, both to
The King and her? why, theſe are prodigies
Indeed. How ſinne imboldens the aſpect!
She doth accuſe me for a guilt, which yet
Remaines vnpardon'd in her ſelfe. Mine was
A dire miſtake: but hers—that muſt be knowne,
And then her veines ſhall weepe.

sp.speaker: Vald.
sp.p: You are poyſon'd, Paradine.

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.p: With that cold draught you ſent me now ith' Bowle?

sp.speaker: Vald.
sp.l: The Vipers vomit, nor the blue ſteame,
Which fat Toades doe breathe in tired motion,
Beares not ſuch a dangerous enmitie
'Gainſt humane Nature, as that you drunke.

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: Stay! Me thinks I feele no inſurrection
In my blood, nor need an Iron Corſelet
To containe my fleſh; ſure it ſwels not yet.

sp.speaker: Vald.
sp.l: It takes a ſubtill leaſure to diſperſe
Thorow all your Organs, and your Arteries,
That it may ſtraite with abler violence
Conſume your ſtrength.

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: And then I ſhall look goggle-ey'd! and ſtretch
Ith' cheekes, till my face ſhew like a Pompeon,
Round and yellow?

sp.speaker: Vald.
sp.p: Farre, farre more deform'd.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Will't make my eies ſtart from my skull, or drop
Like bullets at my feete? Speake, ſhall I fome
At mouth like ſome young Courſer, that is hot
And angry with his bit?

sp.speaker: Vald.
sp.l: Not the firſt Chaos was ſo vgly and
Confus'd, as you'll appeare, when this diſtilment works.

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: Yet I forgiue you all, e'en from my heart:
Whilſt my cogitations now are ſober,
And can diſtinguiſh things with pregnant ſenſe.
I doe applaude this cruell benefit.
Theſe ſubtill vanities of Court haue tyr'd
My obſeruation. I was nourc'd within
Some Armory, and tooke a proud delight
In actiue Warre; but ſince our Drummes haue ceas'd
Their noble clamour, I finde no buſineſſe
Vpon Earth for me; tis fit I grow immortall.

sp.speaker: Vald.
sp.l: I did not thinke, his fancy, at this newes,
Could proue ſo temperate.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: To ſleepe in cold earth, whilſt my dead neighbour
Neuer at my Coffin knocks, to inquire my health,
By way of viſit: for all are ſilent
In the graue. Harſh deſtiny! Such as I
Could ne'r expect from thee, Valdaura.

sp.speaker: Vald.
sp.l: My nature you ſhall finde much different,
From what your knowledge heretofore diſcern'd.
I haue contriu'd another way to puniſh
Thy adulterous heate.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: You find my ſufferance tame enough. Publiſh all!

sp.speaker: Vald.
sp.l: To meet your ſin with apt reuenge, I'm growne
A foule looſe whore.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Hah! containe thy ſpeech. Expreſſe but ſo much
Modeſty, as may ſecure thy life: for
My death doth not concerne my rage ſo much,
As this foule murder of thy fame.

sp.speaker: Vald.
sp.p: Tis truth: and I confirm't with pride.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Oh, oh! theſe are the Mandrakes groanes (fatall!)
For whoſo heares them, ſtraight incounters death.
Now ſmile (ſweet Heauen) ſince thus I but returne
Her owne iuſtice. For my adulterous act,
She takes my life, and ſhall I let that bold
Adultereſſe liue?— Stabs her with 's Ponyard.

sp.speaker: Vald.
sp.l: Oh, oh! Hold, hold! Leaue me a little breath
To vſe in prayer.

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: I am not fraught with diuels ſpleene; I would
Not hurt thy ſoule: here ſolitary ſit,
Whilſt I ſend vp an humble ſacrifice,
That ſhall beſpeake a pardon for thy crime,
Ere thou ariue neere heauen. Puts her in a Chaire.

sp.speaker: Vald.
sp.p: Dare you truſt my laſt vtterance?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: O ſpeak, ere thou doſt catch an euerlaſting cold,
And ſhalt be heard no more.

sp.speaker: Vald.
sp.l: I am not falſe vnto your bed: I ne'r
In act, nor guilty thought, did violate
My Marriage vowes.

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.p: Art thou not a Whore?

sp.speaker: Vald.
sp.l: No Veſtall that preſeru'd with quickning oyle,
The ſacred flame, was in her chaſtity
More cold, more timorous then I: nor are
You poyſon'd.

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: Hah! was not that a mixture of diſtill'd
Venome, which I drunke?

sp.speaker: Vald.
sp.l: 'Twas healthfull, as the blood of Grapes to age,
And all your faculties doe ſtill preſerue
Their wonted harmony.

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: Sweet ſpirit, doe not riddle thus with Heauen,
Nor ſport thy ſoule away. Why didſt accuſe
Thy ſelfe of ſterne murder, and pernicious luſt;
Yet art thus cleere from both?

sp.speaker: Vald.
sp.l: 'Twas to inrage your violence, with hope
To make you ſoone my executioner.
For hearing you were falſe, I found no ioy
In life: your hand hath ſeal'd my wiſhes.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: New Arts t'increaſe my wonder: I'm orereach'd,
Where I thought my nature was moſt skilfull!
E'en in loue! O ſtay: had not diſtraction
Ceaz'd my memory; I ſhould at firſt haue told you
The miſtake, by which the ſinfull Queene
And Hermegild betray'd my chaſte Honour.

sp.speaker: Vald.
sp.l: Nam'd you Hermegild, guilty of that ſinne?
He's then a horrid hypocrite: he did
Entice me by a poyſonous practice to
Contriue your death, but found my nature loyall.

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.p: New wonders ſtill!

sp.speaker: Vald.
sp.p: I feele the frozen hand of death. Oh! oh! oh!

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.p: Valdaura! Bride! Onoble Girle!

sp.speaker: Vald.
sp.p: Mercy! mercy!

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: Already turn'd a Ghoſt! There's rare muſicke
Now in heauen, ſince thou art gone t'increaſe
The ſacred Quire. I may behold thee in
The purple skie, mix'd there with other Starres,
But neuer on this ſoile agen. Be this
Thy Tombe awhile. The Curtaines ſoftly drawne—
Hermegild treacherous! with poyſon too?
That was her word. Tis fit I ſeeme t' haue drunke
The med'cine vp. Good! The rough young Souldier
May ſpie at laſt theſe ſpirits of the Court,
That walke in artificiall clouds: or if
Their high conceptions ſoare aboue my reach,
Yet they haue mortall hearts; ſuch as our owne
Country ſteele, may with feeble motion prick,
Pricke till they groane: for I haue now decreed,
Whom my dull ſenſe cannot ſubdue, ſhall bleed. Exit.

div.head: Act the fifth. Scene firſt.

sp.speaker: Theſ.
sp.p: Shall I belye my owne ſilence?

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: Be ſudden in your ſpeech! confirme my words:
Then diſpoſe e'en of my wealth and perſon.
I will conſent to matrimony; make
Any vſe of this new intereſt.

sp.speaker: Theſ.
sp.p: Sir, you'll forget my merit in this danger?

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: Neuer.— My Lord, I haue diſcouer'd all.
See, how aguiſh her guilt hath made her.
How ſhe trembles like a froſty Ruſſian
On a hill. Nay, Lady, nere ſcatter thus
Your wilde lookes. Confeſſe the truth, and you'll gaine
Mercy. Valdaura (whoſe Soule Heauen keepe
From purging fires) hath told her Lord; the King
Knowes of his wanton ſtealth with our good Queene.
You were the Inſtrument that betray'd him
To th'miſtake, and whoſe ſecrecy to doubt
But yours, our reaſon cannot yet informe vs.

sp.speaker: Theſ.
sp.l: Thus kneeling, I confeſſe with penitence,
'T was I reueal'd it to the King.

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.l: Teare forth her eies, and let her then grope out
Her way to hell—

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.p: Stay, deare Madame!

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.l: Paradine is poyſon'd, who knowes, but ſhe
Doth amply ſhare in that guilt too?

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: At my humble ſute, containe your fury!
We ſhall diſcouer all. My noble Lord,
It is a griefe that will depriue my life
Of many yeeres, to thinke, I'm held by your
Suſpect, an Agent in that practice.

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: I haue reueal'd the euidence, that doth
Perſwade my Creede.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: What, Lady, doe you know of this?—Speak with
Courage, I am your ſafety.

sp.speaker: Theſ.
sp.l: I ſaw the King reach to Valdaura's hand
A poyſonous violl; and with religious hints,
Taught her to mixe it in her husbands draught.

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.p: Hah!

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.p: Perſiſt in my inſtructions! Aſide.

sp.speaker: Theſ.
sp.l: 'T was that night when he enioy'd her perſon—

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.p: Inioy'd her! how?

sp.speaker: Theſ.
sp.p: As you inioy'd the Queene.

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.p: Heauen! will theſe miracles ne'r ceaſe?

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.p: I ſhall conuert to ſtone!

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: Now retire, Theſina, till I haue begg'd
Your free reſtorement to the Queene's mercy.

sp.speaker: Theſ.
sp.l: My Lord, you'll not forget your kind promiſe
Of matrimony.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: I'ue nought elſe, to trouble my remembrance.
Away, Away!

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.l: What did remaine ſuſpence, is heere confirm'd:
My forehead feeles as rugged now as his.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: Now Sir, y'haue heard ſuch reall circumſtance,
As needs muſt ſettle your beliefe, and free
My heart, from your vnkind diſlike.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Valdaura's damn'd! ſhe howles ſo loude, that ſhe
Diſturbes all hell! O periur'd Whore!

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.l: Now Paradine! Inſtruct thy ſelfe with thoughts.
Is't euident he euer could affect
Thy perſon with ſincere dotage, yet thus
Betray thy ſtrength in thy Fort? Where thy
Honor ſtill ſtood ſentinell?

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: I haue other motiues to teach you doubt
His loyaltie in loue. Which my fond heart
Cannot conceale, though't would aduantage much
My owne profit. He hath of late, hung thus—
Vpon my neck; vntill his amorous weight
Became my burden: and then lay ſlabbering o're
My lips; like ſome rhumatick Babe. This ſport
My ſerious braine abhor'd. 'Twas my wonder
(Since you are cal'd his Minion) he could ere
Affect my looke. I that am like coffing
Winter, old, and froward; you the darling
Of the luſty Spring.

sp.speaker: Rho.
sp.l: Speak, is that Bag, that ſhould containe thy Gall,
Shrunke vp; haſt thou nothing bitter in thee?
Thou art farre, farre more opportunely ſtor'd
With time and place for thy reuenge, then wee.
Ith' middle age of day; when the bright Sunne
Moſt powerfully doth warme the world; in thy
Secret Clozet he takes his vſuall ſleepe.
Goe, drill his heart! and make the Couch whereon
He lyes, his eaſie monument.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: And then enioy a Queene, with all that doth
Belong to her atchieuement, or her birth.
As for my ſeruices, they merit no
Reward. I know my owne creation much
Vnfit for Court affaires. If you but wrap
Me in a ſhirt of haire, then ſeate me in
A darke and gloomy Cell, where I may tumble o're
Some deepe voluminous Rabbin, you make
Me ſafe, and happy.

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.l: Doe't, Paradine! and Fame no Trumpet then
Shall neede to ſpeake thy praiſe. Thy Country will
Afford thee power to ſanctifie the chiefe
O'th' dayes within our Kalender.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: And to thy memory high Statues build,
'Bout which our Nobleſt virgins once a yeere
Shall dance in Circles, and ſing, vntill they make
The Marble mooue, like to thoſe looſe Quarries;
Which ore-heard Orpheus and his Harp. Or if
Theſe cannot inſpire heroique fury,
Yet argue thus; you knew his Bed, but by
Miſtake; which was our guilt, not yours; and for
Our Countries benefit contriu'd. But he
Defil'd your ſheets in the ſalt pride of luſt.
Horror! this would incenſe the temperate Doue;
Turne all his moyſture into gall; teach him
To weare ſpurres on his heeles, and make him fierce
In Duell, as a Britiſh Cocke.

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: Fier! fier! and warme blood! Exit.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: Follow, follow him, my deare Soueraigne!
Adde new heate vnto his rage. And d'ye heare!
Since he is poyſon'd, 'twere moſt fit, ſome learn'd
Phyſicion, did indeuour to ſecure
His health.

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.l: I heard him ſay, he is already furniſh'd
With a powerfull med'cine.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: Should you now forget your Royall promiſe,
I loſe all my induſtrious merit,
And remaine a ſacrifice to loue.

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.p: Doſt thou grow iealous?

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: Valdaura now is ſeuer'd from her Soule:
And Paradine is abler in delights
Of Youth, more moyſt and amorous then I.

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.p: Away foole! I ſeale thy ſafety with my lip. exit.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: Thus Nurces huſh their froward babes aſleep.
Shortly ſhe'le preſent me with a Corall-club,
A Whiſtle ſtrung with Bells. Theſe femall Arts
Can ne'r my darke authenticke practice cheate.
Paradine muſt die! So I ſtill ſecure
My hopes. VVhen that ſad houre arriues,
Wherein the poyſonous draught muſt worke,
No charmed med'cine can reſiſt its ſtrength.
I hugge my Genius! 'T was a ſubtill reach,
To tell him, that the King hath horn'd his brow:
For that will more incenſe his wrath, and aggrauate
The Queenes reuenge. The weight I beare, doth make
My motion ſlow: ſlow as the Snaile I tread,
Who trauailes with his tenement on 's head. Exit.

div.stage: Enter Grimold in new Clothes, Gondibert, Vollterri.

sp.speaker: Gond.
sp.p: The King has pay'd him all 's arreres.

sp.speaker: Vollt.
sp.l: 'T was by Theſina's ſute to Hermegild:
The Snake has caſt his skin too now.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: I, Sir, 'tis a poore Snake that cannot caſt,
His skin once in a Summer.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: 'Slight, here's Grimold! Didſt not thou ſay he was dead?

sp.speaker: Conr.
sp.p: But I haue heard ſince, his ghoſt walks.

sp.speaker: Frol.
sp.l: Look! 't has found the hiddē treaſure then, which
Made it walke; for the Ghoſt hath bought it ſelfe
New clothes.

sp.speaker: Grimo.
sp.l: Nay, nay, ſtay, Gentlemen! Let vs forget
Old quarrels, then end our new acquaintance.
We are for the Countrey now. Ile but tell ye
A few of your faults, and leaue th' amendment
To your owne leaſures: but you all thinke
Y'are wiſer then I.

sp.speaker: Cuny.
sp.p: VVe ſhould abuſe our iudgements elſe.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: Mark! This is a new Court-thrift: when you are
Loth to maintaine flatterers, you publiſh
Your ſelues with your owne prayſe. Lay your fingers
Here—Not a word, leſt I returne ye a blow.
I know ye cannot ſpeake without a complement.

sp.speaker: Vollt.
sp.p: They vſe it in their prayers, they.

sp.speaker: Gond.
sp.l: Cunymond, in one ſingle complement
So much waſted his Lungs, that I was faine
To call for Aqua vita to recouer
His breath.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: I'ue heard you haue tranſported from Paris
The Geometricall cringe, and the Art
Of numbring the haires vpon your chins.

sp.speaker: Vollt.
sp.p: And of ſtarching your Beards.

sp.speaker: Gond.
sp.p: Yes, and of perfuming your very ſhadowes.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: And they ſay, it is your cuſtome to ſleepe
In Pomatum Maſques.

sp.speaker: Vollt.
sp.p: And that you paint your prety Vis'gnomies.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: Yes, and colour them ſo red, that you ſeeme
To bluſh more, then the Signe of the Kings head
Before a Country Inne.

sp.speaker: Gond.
sp.l: Y'abuſe Aſtrology too; for you clip
Black-Taffeta into Starres; and for a foile
To your beauty; fix 'em in ſeuerall Regions
Of your face.

sp.speaker: Gri.
sp.l: Which makes it look, like the picture of Doomes-day;
When all the Planets are darkened.

sp.speaker: Vollt.
sp.p: Nay, nay, ſtay awhile!

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: Leaue off your ijgging motion, when you mix
Your ſelues in a ſalute; your bodyes ſeeme
To dance vpon your knees. You pinion vp
Your Elbowes thus:—like Pullets truſt vpon
A ſpit. Then wreath your Hammes in thus; and mooue
With a diſcreet leaſure, as if you meant
To number all the Pibbles in the ſtreet.
And then you fleere, as if y' had waſh'd your gummes
In vineger. This you admire for geſture
Of the neweſt faſhion. I ſay, 'tis skiruy!
For he that greets a Lady ſo, does looke
Like a Sope-boyler, vpon a Cloſe-ſtoole.

sp.speaker: Vollt.
sp.l: If you will take Phyſicke for your ſoules-health,
Retire into that part of the Kingdome
Which lies fartheſt from France.

sp.speaker: Gond.
sp.l: He counſels well: for the French ayre hath made
Many of our Gentry drunke.

sp.speaker: Gri.
sp.l: And now moue hence; but with your lips ſow'd vp,
For feare of a complement. You two ſhall ſtraite
Take horſe with me, and be billited in
My Quarter. Stay, Gentlemen! One word more!
This is a hot Climate: when you muſt needs
Marry to increaſe your Tribe, your beſt way
Is to goe a wooing in the Citie:
For certaine rich widdowes there, loue Court-fooles;
And vſe to play with their bables.

div.stage: A Canopy is drawne, the King is diſcouer'd ſleeping ouer papers: enter Paradine with his ſword drawne.

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: To make him bleed, and leaue his arteries
(VVhere the delighted ſpirits walke) ſhrunke vp,
Vntill they curle with heate. The wither'd frame
Straite to conuert to duſt. Then th' vmerous winde,
To fan it o're the world. Speake, iuſt Heauen!
Is this fit vſage for a King? Caſsius
VVas raſh: perhaps to gaine noiſe at's funerall;
Or in 's Elizian fields; beneath a pleaſant Hedge
To tell ſome prattling ghoſt what he had done—
Hah! but Brutus, noble Brutus! the pride
Of Arts and VVarre: ſo temperate, his ſoule
VVas more harmonious then the Spheares. Inſtruct
(Heroique Lord) thy young Pupill! VVhy did
The mighty Ceſar fall, by thy cold wrath?
All ſilent as the night! He ſleepes: before
Him too, thoſe papers that concerne my houſe
Affaires; and my Officiall rule in State.
Here he comments on my Letters! here with
Thrifty documents limits my expence.
Can this indulgent care be counterfeit?
And meerely carry a pretence of loue? he made
My wife a blacke adultereſſe. O horror!
Yet who knowes, but 'twas rather his reuenge,
Then luſt; a furious riot, after that
He knew I whor'd his Queene—
sp.stage: He blinds his owne face with a ſcarfe, ſheathes his ſword, and then kneeles.
sp.l: Sir! My Lord the King! Sir!

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.l: Hah! Paradine! VVhat witty emblem's this?
The more to certifie thy loue, doſt thou
Appeare blind.

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: O Sir, do not mocke my penitence, nor ſeeme
Thus to diſguize the knowledge of that crime,
VVhich hath defil'd my modeſt bloud, and makes
Me now aſham'd t' incounter with your eyes.

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.p: He is drunke! Maudlin drunke!

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: Sir, I could creepe aliue into my Tombe,
And mixe ſociety with Ghoſts, whilſt I
Haue yet warme motion left, could I but hide
My guilt from your perſpicuous ſight.

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.l: By heauen drunke with Cider, or with thinne Beere;
That lookes like th' vrine of a Babe: I'm ſure
The Corſicke Grape infuſeth no
Such whining paſſion.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Thoſe immateriall powers, that ſee the thoughts of men,
VVhen growing in their hearts, can witneſſe I
Abus'd your Royall bed, but by a dire
Miſtake.

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.p: Hah!

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: Your blacke adulterous Queene betray'd
Me to her luſt by wicked Arts.

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.l: This is a ſober paſſion, but implies
Something that is horrid.

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: Had not heroique warre taught me t' affect
No rage, but noble; ſhe and Hermegild
Had intic'd me now to lengthen this your ſleepe,
Vntill the day of generall accounts.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Suſpect muſt now be raſh. Make your face known!
He bluſhes like a Bride; whom through her thin
Curtaines, the peeping Sunne beholds in ſoft
Skirmiſh with her Lord. I muſt counterfeit,
And ſeeme to know all. Paradine, 'twas farre
From my coniecture, that a heart ſo much
Oblig'd vnto my loue as thine, ſhould wrong
My Honour in a ſenſe, which but to mould
In words would teach my tongue to ſtammer, and
Deafen all that heare it.

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: Thunder and ſulpherous fire ſnatch my cold limmes
From this dull earth. Sir, whilſt my ſoule affords
Me reaſon, and can direct me vnto whom
My true alleageance is a debt, kill me!
When I am mad, I ſhall forget all duty,
And refuſe t' obey your Royall Charter.
Thruſt your good Sword home, till my heart ſhall kiſſe
Your Hilts. Are you ſo ſlow in iuſtice? Thinke,
How by a darke miſtake, I whor'd your Queene:
Whor'd your Queene! O prodigious phraſe!

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.l: Houle, meager Wolues! empty Tygers! let the hoarce
Thracian Bull bellow, till he rent his throat;
And the hot mountaine-Lion rore, vntill
Their clamour wake the dead. The reſurrection
Is too long delayd, ſince we want horror
To celebrate this newes. Good! I haue now
Decreed it. Draw thy bright weapon!—

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.p: For what dire vſe?

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.l: That we may meet in ſingle battaile here,
And ſtruggle till we want our Soules.

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: Though this high inticement charmes my blood, like
The muſicke of the Drumme. Yet my remembrance
Calls you King; My Royall Maſter. I would
Not ioyne rebellion and ingratitude
To the prolixe number of my ſinnes.

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.l: O fond, indulgent Boy! I mourne at this
Decay of thy humanity and ſenſe.
Does it become my great being, and my
Glorious name in ſtory, to offend
Without reſiſtance? Draw: and be nimble
In thy motion—

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: I dare not ſo diſgrace my Religion,
And my loue.

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.l: Tis time that I were dead, for I ſhall elſe
Outliue my chiefe prerogatiue. I haue
Forgot how to command. Vnſheath thy Sword!
Or this breach of Duty ſhall teach me think,
I ne'r inioy'd thy reall loue, and 'twas
Not a miſtake, that vſher'd thee to ſinne betweene
My ſheetes, but a conſiderate luſt—

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: No prouocation like to this, could tempt
A danger from my Arme— He drawes.

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.l: Why doſt thou dally thus with feeble motion?
Beare vp! and vſe more violence!

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: Some ſurgery from heauen! Are you hurt, Sir?
You willingly oppos'd your breſt againſt
My ſteele, and neuer ſought t' indanger me
With yours.

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.l: 'Thaſt perform'd, what my wiſh did prophecy:
I'm prickd heere, about the heart; and my veines
Grow empty.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Then glorious war, and all proud circumſtance,
That giues a ſouldier noyſe, for euermore farewell—

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.l: Hold, Paradine. Tis my laſt ſute, that thou ſuruiue
To miniſter a iuſt reuenge on thoſe
Whom I proſcribe, helpe my quiuering Limmes,
And ſeate me in the Chaire—

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: Shall poſteritie read it in ſtory
And beleeue; a Prince that doth deſerue to be
The firſt ith' Liſt of thoſe, that gatherd noyſe
In warre, can be thus couetous t' expire
In ſilence darke. Fall on my fatall point,
And yet command that I ſuruiue the Tragedy!

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.l: 'Twere in me an affectation triuiall
To cheriſh life, now Rhodolinda's falſe.
For ſhould I ſtill preſerue my ſoule in fleſh,
I know my mercy is ſo fond to her;
I ſhould forgiue her all: and wert thou dead,
My hope were then depriu'd of future iuſtice.
Liue to reuenge her falſhood. I know thy heart
So ſincere and noble, that I ſuſpect not thee
A ſharer in her guilt. When thou
Didſt firſt confeſſe th'adulterous crime, ioyn'd with
Thy owne miſtake, through Hermegilds deepe Art,
My faith conceiu'd the truth: for thy Nature
Is much too blunt, and credulous for Court.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Should I but ſpeak each cunning circumſtance—

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.l: Containe thy breath! To heare that told, would make
My ſoule wander in my laſt iourney.
'Till thy relation brought it to my Eare,
I neuer knew her falſe.

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: Still my amazement doth increaſe! Were you
Not told of this before!

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.p: My knowledge only learnt it of thy Tongue.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Stay! Nor with Valdaura, you did ne'r proiect
My death by poyſon?

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.p: Neuer.

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: Yet one reply, then make my ioy exceed
My wonder. Did you neuer in my bed,
Commit a luſtfull ſtealth?

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.p: Angels in that, are not more free from guilt.

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: What Potter made this earthy Skull! pardon
(Deare Valdaura) my dull ſuſpect! Sing out
Thy Hymnes in heauen▪ and neuer liſten more
To my fond ſpeech; for they haue made mee mad!

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.l: I cannot gripe the Ayre. Marke how it ſteales
Through all my knotty Fingers—

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.p: Extaſie!

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.l: Now my laſt, and ſhort minute is ariu'd;
I doe, reſigne my Crowne—

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.p: To whom ſir?

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.l: To him I hate. But be thou ſure, he weare
It not 'till neere his death: for it's a happineſſe
To liue enthron'd, but tis not ſafe to dye
A King.

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.p: He doth peruert my ſenſe.

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.l: Let the Drum ceaſe! Ile haue no more battailes.
He that to waſte his triuiall rage, doth fight
A battaile, rides a Hawking with the diuell.

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.p: Mad as the Northerne winde!

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.l: He ſends a thouſand drinking Animals
To take their flight ith' ayre, whilſt little blacke
Diuels (d'ye not ſee 'em?) They looke like Rauens.
Marke how they prey on thoſe immortall Fowle,
And plume 'em in their Talents! I doe not like
This Falconry: it is too ſad a game
For ſinners—Oh, oh, oh!— Dies.

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: There dy'd the nobleſt Trophey of our war!
The Lombards now haue loſt their victory.
So hardy of creation, his heart-ſtrings
Were as Cordage, tough; crack'd like a Cable,
When the frighted Barke ſtarts from the Anchor.
All that are nours'd in warre, ſhall mourne for thee.
Our Enſignes now we will of Cypreſſe make▪ knocking.
Hah! It is the winde that whispers▪ he must
Be hid. I'm ſure this noyſe can neuer wake him—
sp.stage: He puts him behind the Arras, opens the doore, enter Rhodolinda.
sp.l: O, are ye come?

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.p: Thou haſt a wilde aſpect! Is it done?

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: He has paid for his wharfage already,
And is now entring Charons Boate.

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.p: Th'art precious as my Soule! He opes the Arras.

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.p: There's the old Face.

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.l: He lookes like a pale Country Virgin
That long'd to eate Morter. Our chiefe deſigne
Is finiſh'd: but thou muſt adde one knot more
T' obliege my gratitude, and then we ſhall
Triumph with ſafety. Hermegild muſt die▪
He knowes too much.

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: It is as if the Parca ſpoke. If there
Be any other whom your enuy, or
Your hate would haue diſmiſt the world, make him
But knowne, and he is numbred with the dead.

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.l: Deare Paradine, I ſure ſhall 〈◊〉 thee,
My appetite is growne ſo fierce. Let me
Begin with thy moyſt lip— Pulls her to kiſſe him in the Chaire.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: Let's to't like Monkeys, or the reeking Goat.

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.p: Oh! oh! oh! Helpe! helpe!

div.stage: Both are bloody about their mouthes.

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.p: Ceaſe your loud clamor, Royall Whore.

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.p: Thou didſt eate my lips.

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: Thy fleſh is ſowre, muſty; more tainted then
A Carion in a phlegmatick ditch for elſe
Like th' Anthropophagus, I had deuour'd thee vp.
This made Valdaura bleed, and muſt let forth
Thy ſwarthy ſoule— Stabs her with his Poniard.

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.p: Oh! oh! oh!—

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: For Albouine my Royall Maſter, this—
And this to pacifie Valdaura's Ghoſt—

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.p: Oh, oh, oh!

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: So hard and ſtony is thy heart, that it
Reuerts the point of my bright ſteele.

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.p: Mercy Heauen! She dies.

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: Since thou haſt receiu'd my iuſtice, I wiſh
Thee mercy too— Knocking.

sp.speaker: Hermegild
sp.l: My Lord.

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: Tis Hermegild, now I ſhall end my chiefe
Diſcouery. What a full Sepulcher is this— Carries her in. Knocking agen.
Now I muſt practiſe my diſguize. Reuert
The Springe twice, and you may enter.

sp.speaker: Theſ.
sp.l: My Lord, I haue loſt my honor in your ſeruice,
You may chuſe one that ſhall affect you worſe.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: Lady, this is no time to woo: but
D'ye thinke I'm ſo prophane to violate
My vow? Nimbly depart, I doe coniure
Your abſence with this kiſſe—

sp.speaker: Theſ.
sp.l: If you ſhould proue falſe—

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: 'Slight, theſe Wenches at
Fifteene, are as riotous as Elephants.
Marry a Court Kitten! There he ſits! Hah, ſick!
My ſweet Lord, how thriues your health? D'your pulſes
Still preſerue their temp'rate muſicke? haue you
Effected yet our great buſineſſe?

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: The King is dead, that ſanguine inſtrument
Did ſet his Soule at liberty.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: The Lawrell, Mertle, and the Bay ſhall ſtill
Cold and naked ſtand before the Winters
Froſty breath; ſtill ſtrip their Boughes, to make
Your head triumphant wreathes. Where is the Queene?
Me thinks (my Lord) your body and your minde
Seeme much diſturb'd.

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: Oh, oh! the poyſon works—

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: Alas, my ſweet deare Lord! (precious med'cine!)
He cannot poſſibly ſuruiue the next
Minute. Does it deſtroy your ſtrength?

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: Oh, oh! It skorches all my entrailes vp:
As if like Porcia I had ſwallowed coales.
I ſpit ſcumme, ſuch as o're th' hot Caldron boyles—

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.p: And are you faſtned in the chaire with weaknes?

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: I cannot riſe. A ſtiffe conuulſion in
My Sinnewes fetters all my limmes—

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.p: Hah! hah! ha!

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.p: O heauen, will you permit him laugh?

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: I know th'Ingredients of thy poyſnous draught.
'Twas I that gaue it to thy wife. 'Twas I
Did counſell her to mingle it in thy wine,
When thou wert hot, and all thy Pores open
As thy mouth.

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.p: Oh, oh, oh!

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: Doe, groane, till thou raiſe an eccho in this
Square roofe. Ere long thy Ribs will ſtart from thy
Looſe Chine, thy lanke Belly ſwell into a hill.

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.p: O horror! horror! Is Heauen aſleepe?

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: The King ne'r knew of thy adultrous crime▪
'Twas I told it to Valdaura, and made
Her thinke, thy guilt proceeded not from a
Miſtake, but from thy wilfull luſt▪ I'ue ſtrung
Thy Noſthrill with a ſpinners thread, ſo led
Thee through ſubtill Labyrinths, t'inuolue
Thy ſenſes; and now I triumph o're thy fate.
This is Italian Spleene.

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.p: Had I but ſtrength to actuate my reuenge?

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: Good, dull Souldier! why didſt thou leaue the Camp,
Thy ruſty Moriō there; thy batter'd Corſelet;
And thy ſhiuer'd Lance, t' amble here at Court
In ſlippery ſilkes; to walke in cloudy miſts
Of perfum'd ayre? Tis I haue ſhak'd thy braines
That heretofore were thicke as Curds, into
A pale, thin whay.

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: Draw neere, and let me then but kill thee—

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: Troth, thou art ſo feeble now, that were I kill'd
By thee, I ſcarce ſhould thinke that I were dead.

div.stage: Paradine riſes, and ſnatches Hermegilds ſword from his ſide.

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: No! that ſhall arriue vnto the 〈◊〉 . Dog! grim
As th'angry Fiend, that muſt deuoure thy ſoule!
I am not poyſon'd.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.p: Hah! does he counterfeit?

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: See heere, what abiect ruines thou haſt made
O'the nobleſt ſtructures in the world—

div.stage: He drawes the Arras, and diſcouers Albouine, Rhodolinda, Valdaura, dead in Chaires.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: The Queene there too! O triuiall Arts with my
Owne Myne I'ue blowne my ſelfe e'en into duſt!

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: I will now ſee, if thou canſt bleed like things mortall—

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: Depriu'd of my defence! If th'aſt a ſoule
(Great as thy fame) reſtore my Sword.

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: Thou bark'ſt againſt the Moone! I will requite
Thy owne tyrannous ſcorne. That deſtinie
Was iuſt, that thus betray'd thee to my mirth.
There, Stygian Dogge— Wounds him.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: Oh, oh! whilſt I haue warmth, Ile moue with violence—

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: Where now are all the ſubtill Tropheys of
Thy braine? Plots, darke as hell! proiections grimme!
Such, as threatned Nature, and ſeem'd to fright
The Genius of the world. Now, now preuent
Theſe dire ſalutes—

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: Returne my Sword, then manage Steeples like
To Pikes; yet, Ile affront thy fury—

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Hardy as the Scythians race, I greet thy heart—

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.p: I ſtagger, and am drunk with my owne blood!—

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.p: Take my laſt anger, and good night! Falles.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.p: Oh, oh! thou haſt ſtuck Needles in my heart!

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: Now I doe ſwell with horror and ſterne rage:
I will diſtract the whole world. Fire! fire! fire!
Murder, Treaſon, & inceſtuous rapes! Fire! fire! Exit.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: I ſpie
A white Soule houering in the ayre! one when
Corporeall, was ſure ſome humble Hermit
Here on earth. He's acquainted with the way
To Heauen: ſhould mine take flight alone, I feare
'T would ſtray! Hoa! you, you that aſcend the Spheares!
We ſinners ſtill ſeeme hoarce to Angels eares.
VVhat, hoa! he turnes not yet: who knowes but he
Still liu'd in low Valleyes, built his Manſion
In ſome ag'd wall? but my path euer lay
On hills, where the good Patriarkes neuer trod.
Vaine Arts! Ambition in all ſacred Schooles,
Is held the ſinne of Heathens, and of Fooles. He dies.

stage.hi: Enter Paradine, Gouernor, Cunymond, Conrade, Frollo, the Guard, &c.

sp.speaker: Gouer.
sp.l: O dire and tragick ſight! The King, the Queene
And faire Valdaura ſlaine!

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: Heere's another obiect fit for wonder,
Though not for pitty. Spurnes Hermegild.

sp.speaker: Gou.
sp.l: Hah! he dead too? Whence ſhould theſe ſorrowes flow?
Lay hold on Paradine.

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: All ſtay. Ile bore his haggard ſoule that ſtriues
With ſawcy ſtrength, to captiuate my Limmes:
Harke, the bigge drumme recouers breath, and ſpeakes!
March on! The ſcatter'd foe retires, and all
The glorious Horſe are ſlaine. I am magnanimous,
And high! O ye vnkind falſe ſtarres! ye mocke
Poore Paradine! A few cleane Teares to waſh
My ſinnes away, and I am ſeene no more.

sp.speaker: Gouern.
sp.p: Ceaze on him; on forfeit of your liues!

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: Their liues are forfeited to me —
sp.stage: He fights with the Guard, they wound and diſarme him.
sp.l: Heere, heere, it gauld my very heart!—

sp.speaker: Gouernor.
sp.l: Conuay him gently in, and vſe all helpe
Of ſurgery to ſtop his wounds: for from
His mouth, wee muſt receiue the knowledge of
Theſe fatall deeds. Some giue th'Allarum to
The Ports! You Siginors, leade to th'Cittadell;
Where, we'le proclaime Albouines young Iſſue
By's former wife, to bee his lawfull heire.
Wilde Fancy may proiect things ſtrange and new:
But Time records no Tale ſo ſad, and true.
